novel_text:
Broken Arrow smells like brick dust and summer church potlucks. In the Rose District on a Friday night you can hear three different bands tuning three different wrong notes while the wind tries to convince you to go home. The bricks on Main carry heat into September, and people walk their dogs twice, once before sunset, once after, when the mosquitoes send smoke signals from the crepe myrtles. I’m usually somewhere between the craft store that sells scented candles shaped like snow cones and the bar that pretends it’s not a bar by offering hummus. I’m usually somewhere between being someone and the punch line I’ve been rehearsing about it.

When you have to explain you’re a comedian in Broken Arrow, you end up folding laundry a lot while you explain, because explaining and folding both make you look responsible. You make little rows of socks on a couch with a sinkhole in the middle and say, no, it’s not just jokes. It’s like—storytelling, but with rhythm; it’s like church but with swears; it’s like sparring but you’re the one both throwing and catching. Half the time you end up talking to someone who can’t stay because they heard the 10 p.m. siren test is tonight (it isn’t; it’s always noon on Saturdays, but fear doesn’t own a calendar). It’s okay. I carry my own calendar in my throat.

Onstage the light is close and bright and unflattering. It likes to show my pores and leave my eyes in shadow. It likes to make me a little ghostly, like I’m borrowing a body I’m not done paying for yet. I know exactly where to stand so I don’t squeal into the speakers, and I grip the mic not like a lover or a weapon but like a handhold, like one of those barn handles you find on old doors at Reasor’s when you think a bakery case might just roll open and reveal a better self.

Tonight, I talk about the way the giant cross on the highway is both comforting and threatening, like an ex who sends you recipes. I say, “We have more churches than stoplights and that math checks out ‘cause every time I stop, someone’s getting saved.” People laugh in that cheap-seats way that tells you they want to laugh. I talk about QuikTrip, my second home, how the soda machines are a baptism if you mix them right, Dr Pepper and regret and just a splash of diet because maybe I’m different now. I talk about growing up here, how the sky moves like a very slow animal, how the weather app is a horoscope with anxiety. People hunch forward and let me move inside their heads for a few minutes. I always put the furniture back where I found it.

June is at the back table, her elbow on the small wooden square like she’s holding it down, like the table might float if she doesn’t. June’s hair is dark and has a mind that wandered off and never returned. She wears a shirt she stole from her sister, a faded navy thing with a hole near the hem that she pretends is a design feature. June laughs without forcing it, a little inward fall of sound, more breath than noise. She is my best friend, which is the easiest story to tell when the light asks a question. Onstage I call her my “accomplice” because it sounds less like falling.

After the set I slide my palm under the mic stand’s foot to keep it from biting me and set everything back in its upright and locked positions. The bartender gives me a nod that could mean I did a job or I did them a favor or that I exist. The light leaves without turning off and the room remembers it’s a room.

“You shaved, kind of,” June says, when I get to her.

“There was a razor in the house and it was time for our talk,” I say. “You sat through the joke about the midi-length skirts of my youth. Again. I owe you a medal.”

“You owe me a pretzel,” she says. “You insulted my sister’s church and the pretzel can be a crumbly apology.”

“Pretzel’s on me.”

“The salt,” she adds. “I want extra. The salt’s on you, too.”

We walk out into the air that tastes like the back of a spoon. Broken Arrow at night makes a kind of stitched darkness, streetlamps sewing the thing together, and the brick glows because brick is dramatic like that. A man bikes past with a loaf of bread under his arm like a baton and no egg in the world will be safe tonight. We pass the plant shop where everything in the window looks like it could listen to you. It’s early for us. We are late for people with babies.

At QuikTrip, the men in reflective vests stand in a small parliament near the coffee urns and discuss weather like weather is gossip. We order the pretzel, and I perform a minor miracle with the cheese cup, not spilling any while I pull the tray to the table we always pick, the one near the wall that pretends to be black tile.

June dips a bite and says, “I love watching you be brave and also safe at the same time.”

“Define safe,” I say, because it tickles.

“Like, you hold the railing with words. You stand close to the thing that won’t hurt you so the thing that can is confused,” she says. “I envy that. I don’t have that. I always take my hands off the bar right when the ride starts.”

We have known each other for three years now. We met at a pottery class we both signed up for because someone’s therapist—hers? mine? does it matter?—said it might help to make something with your hands. The room smelled like wet bread and floor cleaner, and the teacher, a thin man whose right shoulder was higher than his left shoulder, said: center your clay, center your breath, center whatever you’re pretending you don’t have to center. June’s bowl became a plate became a flat circle became a gesture. My bowl stayed a bowl, heavy as a bad mood, and I made a joke about spooning my feelings, and June laughed like her lungs were surprised. After, we threw our pieces in the discard bin that the teacher, jovial, called “the democracy,” and we went to QuikTrip, because QuikTrip is the only confession booth that takes debit.

Now June licks salt from her thumb and her eyelids lower and lift in slow half-moon blinks. She’s a potter still, or whatever the word is for someone who has a wheel in the garage that mostly holds other things but sometimes holds clay. The wheel came from a Craigslist ad that sounded like a breakup: “Needs a good home. Still works. Some scratches. It deserves better.” She’s been throwing more lately, and there are cups drying in her kitchen like a tiny congregation seeing if it can be faithful.

“Can I tell you something?” she asks. The fluorescent lights do what fluorescent lights have always done, which is try very hard to be the sun and fail.

“Only if I can tell you something back.”

“Deal,” she says. The salt crystals on the tray make constellations if you squint, which is how most constellations happened in the first place.

“I think you’re getting better,” she says. “I know you hate that word. I know it’s like telling a cloud it’s doing a great job being a cloud. But I can see the timing shifting, like you moved your couch and suddenly you can breathe. Your breath, Rachele. Onstage it’s yours tonight.”

I pretend to look at my phone because receiving kindness is not my talent. “Okay my turn,” I say. “I saw your cups. The small blue one? You got the lip right. I don’t know what makes a lip right, but whatever it is you wrestled it to the ground and you are standing on its throat.”

She snorts and covers her mouth. “God.”

“I will not apologize for metaphor violence,” I say, solemn. “Not in this QuikTrip. Not while the roller grill dreams of becoming food.”

We eat in the way that friends do when they have run out of stories about other people. The world is in the corner of my eye, doing its juggling. A teenager with a basketball under the counter asks for cigarettes he cannot have. A woman in scrubs buys agua fresca and a scratch ticket and a sigh. The door sussurra, lets in a new piece of night.

I love June the way you love a song you can’t sing along to yet because you don’t know it, not in your mouth. I love June the way midsummer loves a thunderhead, suspicious and plain and wanting. I put my hands near it and then remember I am electricity and also a person, and I pull back. Instead I keep feeding it tiny coins of admiration and jokes, hoping one day the machine vends something I can name.

We leave when a group of teenagers colonize the chairs and start throwing napkins like flags. Out in the parking lot, a pickup slides past with a dog in the passenger seat sitting like he’s late for a meeting. The amber light at the edge of the lot makes everything look like it might be in a memory.

June goes to her car and pulls on the door like it’s pretending not to know her. There is a sound of plastic disagreeing with plastic. “Don’t judge my door,” she says when it finally opens. “It’s had a week.”

“I would never judge your door,” I say. “I only judge your Playlist of Sad Women With Banjo.”

“They aren’t sad,” she says. “They’re precise.”

She drives a tan Camry with a bumper sticker that says Support Your Local Library and a small chip on the windshield that looks like a comma, as if the road asked her to pause. When she pulls out, she looks left, right, left again, like the manual taught her, like the manual was a god. She drives with both hands, ten and two, as if the car could slip out of her fingers at any second. I used to think that was cute. Now I think everything she does is a small letter to the future in case the future wants to reply.

“Ferris wheel?” she asks, one hand out her window, catching the air in its palm like it could hold it. The small traveling carnival set up a week ago on the edge of Elm Place, for fundraising something or other and the Ferris wheel is older than my father’s truck and a miracle that refuses to learn about load-bearing beams.

“I have to write,” I say, and it’s true, and also the Ferris wheel makes my stomach test me. “Also I promised my mom I’d stop riding things that were assembled by men named Ron in shorts.”

“Ron in shorts,” she says, like a poem’s first line. “We’ll go tomorrow and I’ll make fun of you from below.”

I want to say come over. I want to say I bought blueberries and forgot why. I want to say I want to fall asleep with the sound of your dishwasher like a small river I’m allowed to cross. Instead, I wave like people wave in cars, like the movement could be a shield. She pulls away, and brake lights stain the asphalt for a second, and then night returns to its default setting.

Home is a third floor apartment with two windows that fight about light. The ceilings are high not because the building wants to be generous but because someone mismeasured something. The carpet was beige once and now is committed to a complicated neutrality. My couch is a gray you can find in any therapist’s office if you dig. The bookshelf wobbles and my landlord insists the wobble is part of the charm, as if gravity is a personality trait. I know the names of the crickets by the balcony because we share the hours. They keep time for me. I set my notebook on the coffee table and the coffee table pretends that was always its meaning.

I write in long loops. I talk to myself in a voice that doesn’t always like me. I make lists as if the lists can forgive me. I circle words and uncircle them. I try to put the air from QuikTrip into the paper, the way the woman in scrubs looked like a secret she was keeping, the way June’s thumb was a small planet collecting salt. Sometimes I think if I just name everything carefully enough, the world will calm down. Name and tame—a rhyme I should be more suspicious of.

When I don’t write, I walk. Not like the long day will vanish if I outpace it, but like walking is the opposite of erasing. I walk down to the skate park where small boys fly past like they got a memo about gravity and have chosen to respond creatively. I walk past the old train car they shoved near the museum, a thing that never moved again but still looks like it might if you looked away. I walk the parking lot of the church where my mother sings alto in a choir robe that makes her look like herself and not a substitute teacher. I walk to sleep, sometimes, and if sleep refuses, I carry on without her.

My mother calls at eleven and says, “I watched that clip you sent.”

“Mom,” I say, and sit down on the floor because her voice is a room with a different gravity. “Was it too much? The thing about communion crackers? I can cut that.”

“It was bright,” she says. “It was sharp. You have grown into yourself.”

“I stole that exact sentence for a joke about puberty.”

“You steal from me all the time,” she says, and I hear her smile because you can. “Your grandma would have loved to argue with you about it.”

“Would I have won?”

“No,” she says softly, “but you would have sharpened each other like knives, and that would have been a kind of love. How is June.”

She always says it like that, like June is a status you order from a menu, medium rare.

“She’s good. She’s throwing,” I say. “Cups this time.”

“I saw one on the Instagram. The lip was very elegant. Is she seeing anyone.”

“She sees me all the time.”

“Mhm.”

“Mom,” I say, slow as if the syllable might be the right shape. “Don’t.”

“I am not doing anything. I am stirring soup,” she says. “You tell your jokes and I will stir my soup, and one of us is allowed to be a mother about it. Your father is building a shelf.”

“He cannot trick the wall into holding it,” I say. “The wall knows.”

“The wall is stubborn. It’s where you get it. You were a stubborn baby.”

“I was a principled baby,” I say. “There’s a difference.”

After we hang up, I watch a video of a woman making sourdough with a voiceover like rain. I wash my face and am startled, as always, that my face remains, committed to the job. I lie down and the ceiling hums. The night comes in through the small slit in the blinds like a note someone pushed under the door.

Morning isn’t new in Oklahoma. It’s a second draft. The light is already edited. I make coffee that tastes like a very clean apology and open my notebook to the page where I scrawled dreams: a snake made of ribbon and a man I think was my fifth grade math teacher except he was a tree. I write these down because I promised a therapist once that I would try to respect the weird.

June texts at 9: a photo of a cup with a small wobble. “This one is like your laugh,” she writes. “It keeps wanting to tip into a different joke.”

“You take that back,” I text, and send a picture of my coffee mug, chipped on the lip, the chip I always forget until it cuts my mouth like a friend making a point. “This is me.”

“Blueberries are on sale,” she replies. “We can become baker women who sing.”

“Who are not sad,” I type. “They are precise.”

She sends a voice memo of her own laugh. I play it three times. It’s the exact length of a heartbeat if your heart is trying to be sneaky.

The day is a rehearsal. I go to the grocery store and argue with tomatoes. I pick the line with the woman who will tell me about her child’s soccer practice, because I like to hear about things I cannot fix. I stop by the library and touch the spines of books like they might touch me back. I go to the small studio where a man lets me hold a hand drum and pretend rhythm likes me. At noon, the tornado siren tests. It is a sound that makes time expand, a pressure in your head like weather has an opinion about your bones. Everyone ignores it like professionals. Everyone still looks up.

At five I let my brain do nothing in a parking lot. At six I go to the coffee shop that sells paintings of birds with eyes too human. I run my set in my head and then again in my mouth like mouth rehearsal is different. It is. Rehearsal lives in the body, not the plan.

At seven June texts. “I’m outside,” she says. “I brought the good gum.”

She leans against her car like she and the car have chosen each other for now and are committed to doing the work. She has an orange in her pocket and the orange wants to be seen. We peel it before we go in and our hands smell like we went to a better place.

“You’re wearing the jacket,” I say.

“This is the jacket,” she says. It’s the denim one with the soft places where soft places matter, the elbows, the back. It’s the jacket that says I live here. “I want you to do the joke about the tornado drill.”

“I just wrote the new tags.”

“I want to hear the new tags live.”

“That’s what faith is,” I say, and she rolls her eyes because she grew up in a house where the word faith has a shelf.

Tonight the bar is less of a bar because a group of church women from a nearby Bible study has decided to stay late and “try the craft beer.” They look like an early morning I could love. The host gives them small cups like toddlers, and one of the women says, “Hoppy?” like it is an accusation. They bless themselves with laughter.

When I go up, June is in the place she always is, a little to the left. The light pretends it knows me now. I talk about the way tornado drills taught us to become furniture, to turn our backs to the glass because we didn’t deserve to watch the storm want us. I talk about Okies at the grocery store when the weather decides to pretend we are endangered, all of us buying milk like that will tether the house. I talk about my father, who builds a shelf when anxious. The women from the Bible study laugh and gasp and two clap on the wrong beats and I feel enormous affection for them.

Halfway through the set I make a joke about the road. I say the BA Expressway is a river and we are all paddling with paper plates. I say the way we merge is a spiritual exercise, a willingness to be seen and not crash. I mention drivers who treat turn signals like declarations of war. June’s head tilts like she’s learning something she thought she already knew.

After, a man stops me to say I said something he needed. He doesn’t know what it is but he needed it. He has tears he does not want to have and I offer him a napkin like I am in charge. June buys me an iced tea and we sit on the window ledge like teenagers with nowhere to be.

“You OK?” I say to the man’s receding back because I am a late person, always arriving after the moment arrived.

June stands and stretches like a tall thought. “Let’s walk,” she says, and my bones say yes before I make a face. We walk down Main where the brick argues with concrete and lose the sound of the bar quickly to the sound of us. The air is thick but not mean. The lamps are practicing being stars.

We pass a group of kids taking pictures in front of the mural with the big roses and the word LOVE in letters too wide. They pose like they’ve seen people pose on places that tell you how to pose. I try to see the space like I saw it at thirteen, when I thought everything large was proof.

“Do you ever want to go?” June asks, and it’s the way she asks when what she means is leave, not, do you want to go to the Ferris wheel now. “Like, do you ever want to sell your couch and declare your house a museum and just go?”

“I want to go all the time,” I say. “I want to go and I want to stay and I want both things so much I forget to do either.”

“I thought about Tulsa,” she says, which is our version of Paris. “Just to see. Or maybe the place with the cliffs. Or a coast, a different wet.”

“You’d be enormous somewhere else,” I say, and it comes out more tender than I planned. “This place keeps you small because it knows you. Somewhere else would have to measure again.”

She bumps my shoulder with hers, which is how she says thank you when thank you is too loud. We stop at the edge of the small city park where the grass is considerate and the trees, planted by a committee, haven’t decided on a mood.

“Sometimes I think I should fall in love with someone sensible,” she says, and the way she doesn’t look at me is a kind of looking. “Like a man who decides what to do with numbers. I should hand him my chaos and watch him stack it neatly.”

“If I met a man who could do that I’d marry him first,” I say, and the joke lays there obediently, waiting for the room to catch up. She laughs, the laugh I saved from the memo, and it flickers through me. I want to say, I am not sensible but I am faithful. I want to say, give me your chaos in a paper bag with a grease stain and I will wear it like a hat and we’ll call it a day. I want to say, I baked those blueberries. I didn’t. I don’t bake. The oven is a metaphor I distrust.

Instead I say, “You deserve good mistakes.”

“I am so tired already,” she says, and leans her head on my shoulder for a wild second, and we stare at the grass that has decided to be exactly what it is. Then she stands up straight like a student being called on. “Ferris wheel?” she asks again, and it’s a way of asking, do you want to do something dangerous but small.

“Tomorrow,” I promise. “I have a date with a blank page, and the blank page is late and mean.”

She drives me home. My building’s stairwell smells like someone who once made chili and thinks it’s still going on. We sit in the car with the engine a small animal under the hood, warm and needing.

“Do you ever think about…” she says, and stops.

“Yes,” I say, because I do, about everything, about the way the streetlight makes her cheek a soft coin, about the way my hands know how to be still and don’t want to be.

“I’m going to make you a bowl,” she says instead, a change of subject that isn’t a change. “A bowl so heavy you have to use two hands.”

“Like faith.”

“Like dignity,” she says. “Like soup for the end of the world.”

I go upstairs and sit on the floor and lean against the couch and the air comes in my lungs and goes. I practice saying things to the empty room. I practice not saying things. The crickets take their positions and the highway hums, far away and always near. Sleep finds me not because I am ready but because it has to, like a bus route. I ride it to morning.

The next day starts clean as paper. June sends me a photo of a bowl that is imperfect and holy. I send her a joke about storms. We promise to meet at seven at the Ferris wheel, to go up and look at our small city from the top, to wave at the church steeples and say we live here and it is enough.

Before then, there is the day. There are the errands and the texts and the small tragedies of ordinary hours. I read a poem and forget it and then remember the exact word “cattail” when I pass the drainage ditch. I see a woman teaching her child to ride a bike and the child’s body is outrage and grace at once. I drink water and pretend it is medicinal. I stand too long in a doorway, thinking. I watch a man move a piano with three other men and a rope that I don’t trust, and everything in me makes a sound.

I do my set again, small and tight in the mirror. I listen to the radio because the radio is the only place someone’s voice can change the day. A song about dust makes me tear up at a stop sign. I talk myself down. I call my mother to hear her tidy a drawer with words.

At six-thirty I leave, because I am a person who is not late for Ferris wheels; those are not the rides you want to rush. The sun is lower now and throws the world in relief. Moths already plan their mistakes. I drive past fields that are not fields, past houses that used to be houses. The air feels like it could crack or heal. Both are options. I am always driving through a choice.

My phone buzzes at a red light. June: “Running late. Ten minutes.” The message has a typo, the word running without the second n. It’s the kind of small human mistake that always makes me love us. I send her a thumbs up that pretends to be adequate.

I get there and the wheel turns and turns, a slow idea against the sky. People line up and don’t pretend to be patient. Kids attack the air with sugar. The woman with the cash box takes my money like she’s known me a thousand years and she has. The ground under my shoes is the kind of ground you only find in places meant to be temporary—pressed, uncertain, trying.

I stand by the fence and practice breathing like there’s a correct way. The light around everything is honey on a spoon, reluctant to let go. I imagine the top of the wheel, the way the town will look like a plan someone wrote down and kept. I imagine pointing at the library roof and saying, there. I imagine June’s hand on the cool metal of the carriage, how she would make a joke about creaks, how I would pretend not to be scared. I imagine telling her a truth and not regretting it immediately.

I check my phone again. “On my way,” she writes. A car door slams somewhere. The wheel creaks. A little boy in a Spiderman shirt says loudly that he could jump it if he had to, and his mother says please don’t, and he nods a nod that is also a plan.

Someone laughs. Someone curses, softly, in that local way where cursing is flavor not heat. Someone drops a popcorn bucket and collects the pieces and makes popcorn out of the pieces anyway because waste is a luxury.

I stand there and wait, like a person in a story who hasn’t learned her story yet. The light lowers. The town breathes. Seven becomes seven-ten becomes seven-twenty. June’s car is not here. My phone is silent. I imagine every wrong turn. I imagine a line at the light. I imagine her stopping to look at a hawk like we do, like both of us believe hawks are omens, even on normal days.

The man with the cash box tells me how many tickets there are left because he thinks I’m nervous about scarcity. I smile and say I’m waiting for someone, and he says, “Aren’t we all,” and I smile the kind of smile you give when you know you’re in a line bigger than the one in front of you.

When my phone finally buzzes, it’s not a text. It’s a call. And it’s a voice that doesn’t know me, that knows my number from somewhere else, from a screen in a pocket, from a distance, and it says my name like it’s asking permission to use it, and the world folds in the middle but does not break, not yet. The Ferris wheel turns like it promised. The lights along the spokes flash red, then blue, then white, then nothing like an eyelid trying to focus. A moth wings itself against my cheek and the small dust it leaves is everything I have left in that second, and I hold completely still and then I move. I’m already walking. I don’t know which way yet, but my body does, and I let it, I let it tell the street what it knows before my brain does, and the town looks like my hands when I’m cold, all knuckle and ache, and I go.The voice says my name like it doesn’t belong to me yet and asks if I know a June with dark hair and a denim jacket and a car that looks like a sentence that hasn’t decided how to end. I say yes, more than yes, and the voice says there’s been a thing, a small thing that isn’t small, a kiss between bumpers that turned into a shove. He says she’s awake, he says she said my number first, he says they’re taking her to St. John Broken Arrow because that is the hospital the ambulance knows by heart. He tells me which corner to avoid because traffic has decided to turn into theater and the audience is impatient, and when I say I’m coming, the word “coming” feels like a muscle I forgot I had.

By the time I reach my car I find I’m already moving with the surety you get when there are no options, only momentum. My keys make that dumb chime like the car is flirting, and I tell the dashboard out loud to please pay attention, like electronics respond to tone. The turn out of the lot is a needle through fabric, and the world comes in fast, broken into frames by the streetlights. I pass the Ferris wheel, which has moved from romance to satire in a single minute, and it watches me go with all its eyes. The light on Elm is red and then not; the road becomes a tongue, rough and familiar, and I am the word trying to arrive. I don’t know why my brain decides to notice the teenager in a hoodie pushing a bike uphill, the way he leans into it like he believes in friction, but it is here with me, along with the smell of frying oil escaping a truck bed and the way brake lights make a grammar on pavement I understand without translation.

When the intersection appears it is a story told wrong. The trees on the corner are pretending to mind their own business, but everyone in town knows, because everyone in town has slowed to watch, and this is a kind of prayer we practice even when we say we don’t. The Camry is on the shoulder under a convinced streetlamp, and it still looks like itself, which makes my knees threateningly negotiable. The comma in the windshield has become a sentence fragment, spreading like a thought you tried not to think. A paramedic in navy and competence asks me who I am and when I say “hers,” he nods in a way that translates into a little space where I can see June, propped and watching everything like it owes her a reason.

“Hey,” she says in that breathy stage whisper people use when the stage is a gurney. “I am sorry I stood you up. The airbag had plans for my face.” She gestures with her eyes because her hands are doing their own choreography with straps and blood pressure cuffs, and there is a cut above her eyebrow that looks like a new constellation, and she is very, very June, which means she is making it easier for me even though I don’t deserve it.

“You would cancel a date with God if there was new laundry,” I say, and her grin is a thing that rearranges the night. The nametag on the paramedic reads RON, because sometimes the universe likes its own jokes, and he tells me they are taking her in to keep her for a bit because her head is insisting it’s fine and they don’t believe heads. He says cracked radius maybe, and bruising, and her pulse is a drum with manners, and I nod as if nodding is a useful profession. I sign something with a pen that has touched too many panicked hands, and I say, like an idiot, “Can she have gum,” and Ron smiles with his eyes and says no gum in the ambulance, ma’am, and I hate the ma’am because it recognizes me and I love it because I want the world to be heavy with adults who know what to do.

The ambulance leaves like a punctuation mark and I follow it without outrunning common sense. The BA Expressway opens its throat and lets me in, and I’ve never been so grateful for its brutal clarity, the way it gives you a straight line and dares you to misuse it. The giant cross at the megachurch exit is lit like an idea that refuses to sleep, and in this light it is exactly as confusing as I always say, both movie prop and compass. I think about how many times I’ve made fun of the way we drive around here, and how the jokes were always a way to put my hands somewhere, a railing I could hold while the ride pretends to be wild. The siren ahead of me is a thread through fabric, pulling us toward something that is both answer and question, and when it cuts left under a sign that says Emergency it feels like we have been chosen for a team I didn’t know we were trying out for.

St. John at night is a clean mouth. It smells like mint and the kind of lemon that is really just an idea of lemon, and there are women behind counters who have seen everyone in their ugliest hour and keep greeting the next person as if this is the first time they have ever watched someone arrive full of the need to be forgiven by the present. “Relationship,” the registrar asks, and I hate the ranginess of that word, the way it wants me to stand in a shape that might not be respected by a printer. I say friend because English has not given me a better word I can say in this foyer without melting, and she accepts it like a check that will cash. The pen on its little chain winks at me, and all the forms ask if June is allergic to peanuts and penicillin and hope, and I write no about all the things I know she can handle, and I leave blank the spaces where I don’t know, because I refuse to lie to paperwork even when it is kind.

The waiting room has chairs in colors that are trying to be calm and a television tuned to a travel show where a man with a beard eats something messy and nods as if he understands a place because his mouth is full. There is the requisite woman knitting something that can forgive your wrists, and a man whose foot jiggles to a beat only he hears, and a nurse at a desk whose posture suggests she is holding the ceiling up with her spine. I sit in a place that feels like a corner without being one and discover that sitting is a verb that asks for cooperation from your heart. I text June’s sister because there are vows we make without saying them and one of them is that you do not let sisters find out from the wind, and I write the words carefully like I am placing them under her door. “She’s okay,” I type and delete and type again because I have learned that telling people someone is okay when they are inside a medical building is like promising the weather; it is a kindness that can hit you later. I call my mother because I am now the child asking for the soup of her voice, and she answers in the way that lets me be older and younger at once, and when she says she and her choir will pray like they mean it, I believe in their breath like a quilt.

In the fourth hour of the longest minute, a doctor with a haircut like a decision comes out and says words that stop shaking almost immediately, because he is good at his work and his work includes steadiness. Concussion, he says, like a word we all know from a pamphlet, and a hairline fracture in the left radius, and bruising where life insisted upon itself too hard. He says she was lucky to be wearing her seatbelt like this is a new sacrament and I should make a note. He says they will keep her overnight because brains are drama queens who need to be humored, and tomorrow they will decide what kind of cast June gets to live with. He says I can see her because she asked for the person with the laugh that breaks in the middle, and I recognize myself even when described by someone else’s listening.

June is in a room that pretends to be a room and is really a diagram of safety. There are rails on the bed like we have reached a place in the world where the bed itself needs help being a bed, and the monitor glows in the corner like someone’s idea of a town. Her face is a new topography with medical tape like small bridges, and she smiles the exact smile from the parking lot after a show when someone insists on telling me about their cousin’s bar mitzvah, which is to say she manages to make a space where this is not the worst thing. “Ferris wheel rain check,” she says, and her voice plays at normal and only flinches once at the word wheel.

“I got you the deluxe package,” I say, and hold up the hospital cup of water with a straw like it is priceless and we both know plastic is the only substance that lives forever. She gestures vaguely toward her left and winces only to keep me honest, and I pull the blanket up because there is nothing in the world more useful than rearranging fabric when you can’t rearrange anything else. “You look like you fought a small handsome bird and won,” I say, and she giggles, which makes the monitor add punctuation to our conversation, and I’d marry that ridiculous little beep if it asked.

We talk about the stupidest things because the stupidest things can carry weight without bending. She tells me about the man who ran across two lanes to lean into her window and hold her gaze while he told her which way was up, and she says he smelled like motor oil and generosity and she trusts that combination because her father fixed things more than he hugged them. I tell her about the woman at the front desk with the rhinestone pen who said she liked my earrings like she was pinning me to the map, and I admit I almost cried in the gift shop at the sight of a plush possum wearing a stethoscope, because the world has no idea how close it always is to ridiculous. She dozes and wakes and asks for the time and makes a face when I say it and says, “This was not the miracle I ordered,” and I say, “Delivery services are unreliable,” and she rolls her eyes and the roll is the gentlest thing I’ve ever seen someone do.

There is a moment when she is mostly asleep and the monitors have decided to trust her, and I hold her hand in the way you do with people who prefer to be reminded rather than rescued. Her fingers are warm and unbroken and freckles invent themselves across her knuckles like punctuation in a poem, and I think of the bowl she promised me, the heavy one, and how some things can only be held with both hands if you want to honor them. I consider telling her the thing I practice telling the wall, the thing about wanting her near me in ways I don’t even know how to catalog, but I also consider the timing and the abundance of tubes and the oxygen sensor clipped to her finger like a nightlight that refuses to go off, and I decide lust is brave but love can be patient. The chair at the side of the bed is the kind of chair dreamed up by people who hate chairs, but I fold myself into it and let my spine write new alphabets because being here is easier than being anywhere else.

At two in the morning the world becomes a hallway, and I meet it for coffee like you meet a person you dated once and decided to keep friendly. The vending machine offers choices that are not choices and I feed it a dollar like an offering to a fickle god. I end up with something that claims to be a lemon cookie and tastes like a meeting, and I eat it anyway because this is not a night that requires standards. There is a nurse who moves like a metronome, and her badge says TIFFANY even though she is fifty-five and older than the pearl I imagine in the necklace she refuses to take off, and she tells me quietly that June looks good, that she likes the way June’s numbers behave when the room is bored. This phrase, the room is bored, sits down with me like a friend I didn't know I needed, and I imagine the room itself as a patient, needing us to be either interesting or stable, and tonight we have chosen stable, and tonight I owe the room a snack.

June’s sister calls me back at a time of night that makes apologies into crows, sharp and unnecessary. She says she didn’t hear the text because she was cutting out paper stars for her niece’s school project, and the way she says stars lets me forgive every sharp thing I’ve ever thought about her correctional style of love. We talk about logistics because logistics allow you to move your heart around the map without the heart realizing you’ve left it behind. I tell her I’m here and in love with the beep and she says she will come in the morning with socks because hospital socks are either a religion or a threat and we all have preferences, and she thanks me in the voice of a woman who is surprised to need someone and pleasantly baffled to find they were already there.

At four I walk down to the lobby to remind my body what distance feels like, and on impulse, or on muscle memory, or on the trajectory of a person who has been here before in other shapes, I go across the street to a QuikTrip that is practicing being quiet. The men in reflective vests are not in parliament because parliament sleeps eventually, but there is a single man with a newspaper folded into a language you can turn into a hat, and an older woman pouring coffee who says “Good morning” to me like it’s a dare. I get a pretzel because something circular is required and condiments are control, and I sit for a minute under the fluorescent lights that are trying out new names. I think about June’s hands in clay, the way she finds center not by forcing it but by negotiating, and I try to center myself around nothing, and it goes about as well as negotiations when both parties are stubborn and identical.

Back in the room, the hospital is wrapped in the kind of quiet that still has edges. The windows let in a softness that wants to be morning, and I take the chair again because it has forgiven me. June sleeps with her mouth doing that small thing mouths do when they are busy being a body instead of a person, and I think about all the mouths she keeps, the one she uses with kids at the pottery classes she started teaching on Tuesdays when the radiators hiss and the wheel makes a sound like a child shushing itself, the one she uses with her sister when they pretend not to be the same person in two different decades, the one she uses with me, full of compromises and little fairs where I get to win prizes if I listen closely. I let my eyes close because my eyes are fragile littles who will misbehave if not given their nap, and I sleep there with my hand on the bed in the way people put their palms on the hoods of cars to feel the engine still warm, to believe in the evidence of heat.

When I wake, it is because dawn has decided it is time for the city to remember we are alive. The narrow slice of sky I’m allowed through the window blushes with a color makeup counters call something like coral promise, and the BA Expressway hums its locust song and has the audacity to be almost beautiful. The nurse with the pearl necklace brings in a tray with a plastic dome that has the self-esteem of an astronaut helmet, and June blinks at me from under her lashes like a person rejoining a conversation she never agreed to leave. “So the Ferris wheel,” she says, and it feels miraculous that we still live in a world where this sentence can take up space.

“We will wait until it forgets we owe it money and then we will ride it twice,” I say, and she says, “Twice?” and I say, “Once for me and once for the part of me that didn’t get on,” and she laughs and then winces and then laughs at her own wincing because being human is very layered if you let it be. She eats three bites of hospital eggs that are eggs in the way a paper boat is a boat, and she declares herself a conqueror and lets me tuck the blanket again and I feel useful in a way the stage has never gotten me, which is inconvenient, to be honest.

At some point my phone tells me someone from last night’s show posted a clip of me talking about tornado drills and there are comments from people I don’t know saying the joke made them think about the glass they turn their backs to, and I want to go and delete the whole world and also invite them here to sit in a hospital chair and see what it means to turn toward, but I settle for a heart emoji and a promise to myself that I will not write anything I don’t believe while my bones are tired. My mother texts a photo of my father holding a level like a relic and a shelf he has convinced a wall to respect, and she has added the caption “Stubbornness: a family heirloom,” and I would like to kiss them both on their foreheads and tuck them into a shoebox labeled Persons Who Can Be Counted On.

There is a flurry of scrubs in the hall and a cheerful tech named Marisol who bends the whole day toward her smile. She wraps plaster and says things like almost there and this is going to be your temporary beautiful, and June watches her arm become a statement and says, “It’s like a bracelet that means it,” and Marisol says, “Yes, exactly, a bracelet with boundaries,” and I love them enough to loan them my car. June has to pee and I become a person who helps people pee and I do it like I was born to it, and later, when she is back in the bed, she says, “Thank you for not narrating,” and I say, “I narrate for a living, I know when to let the scene breathe,” and she says, “You are insufferable,” and I say, “Correct,” and this feels like the most honest exchange the hospital has hosted all morning.

By midday she is set free with a list of instructions that reads like a spell, and I sit with her while the nurse explains anti-nausea medicine in a tone that suggests she knows I’m going to forget and call anyway. We leave with a bouquet of plastic containers and the sort of stern promises we make to strangers because we plan to break them to friends. The sunlight in the parking lot is the kind that has no use for metaphor, and I help her into my car, and she carefully arranges her body like a game of Tetris where the shapes have opinions. The seatbelt crosses her chest and she looks at it like a new religion and I consider joining, and together we drive through our city like we didn’t plan on doing this today and are grateful to be allowed.

At her apartment I carry the bag the hospital gives everybody, the one that looks like a reusable grocery bag but feels like a white flag, and I open her front door with the key I have because we have arranged our lives around trust. The air inside smells like Thursday even though it is not, and the wheel in her garage sits like an animal that has been told to stay. I help her to the couch that is honest about what it has been through, and she finds a pillow for her left arm and then finds a better pillow and then finally picks the first pillow, and I put the glass of water on the right side because I have learned from experience about this particular gravity. We draw the blinds halfway because our eyes are relatives with opposing politics, and I sit on the floor with my back against her couch and open my notebook because sometimes the only way through an event is to make it earn its rent.

She closes her eyes and then opens them because she has something to say and does not trust it to stay if she waits. “When the man leaned in and told me which way was up,” she says, “the only thing I could think was, my mother would be proud that I did not panic. Isn’t that stupid?” She says it like she is throwing out compost that will probably turn into something useful if we’re patient.

“I think it’s precise,” I say, and we lie there with precision like a third person in the room, small and necessary and occasionally insufferable. There is a blue shadow on the carpet that can only be made by the exact tilt of light through the slit of the blinds, and our city hums in a register only my bones can hear. Her breath evens out and I write the sentence: It is a privilege to be present for everything someone is trying to become. I write it twice because repeating makes it truer, and then I scratch it out because I am not writing for the audience today, I am writing for the machine that turns experience into the next right thing.

In the late afternoon we both sleep as if we are getting away with something. When we wake, we eat the blueberries with our hands out of the plastic clam shell because no bowl yet deserves them. We sit in our socks and watch a cooking show where everyone cries about onions and this seems like an appropriate compromise with the universe. When the light goes pink as a scraped knee, June says, “Not tonight,” and I say, “No, not tonight,” and we share that promise like a roll at a table we finally feel we were invited to. Tomorrow I will make calls to insurance agents who believe in apocalypse more than humor, and I will stand in line at the pharmacy and make up backstories for everyone else who stands there with their small white bags, and I will drive made-of-jello slow past the intersection where the town took a breath and learned to hold it.

For now, the city softens around us like bread in a warm room. I say, without looking at her because sometimes the eyes get in the way, that we owe ourselves the top of the wheel, and she says, without looking at me because sometimes the eyes are impatient, that we will go when the man with the cash box has forgotten our faces and the moths have moved on to some other flame. We construct tomorrow out of the modest shapes available, and if the room gets bored we will tell it a joke. We will tell it about a cross that looks like a threat and a recipe and how a woman with a cast can still hold a railing with her words. We will tell it about a bowl heavy enough to require both hands and a city light enough to forgive us for not riding the ride on time, and somewhere under all of it there will be a beep, and we will let it keep time because we still plan to dance.The day after we don’t ride the Ferris wheel teaches me the patience of paperwork. Insurance is a whispering chorus that refuses to harmonize, and I pace my living room trying to keep my voice in the key of polite. A woman in another time zone asks me to describe the “incident” and I do, carefully and without adjectives, like adjectives could make it worse. She tells me about a claim number that feels like a phone number I’ll never call again, and I write it in my notebook next to a doodle of a circle with teeth. When I hang up I call the pharmacy because bureaucracy enjoys relay races, and a man with the voice of a high school bass clarinet tells me June’s prescription will be ready “in twenty to forty,” and I ask, twenty to forty what, and he says “You know,” and I do, because time in waiting rooms bends like a straw. The light in my apartment insists on being honest and my plants, anemically loyal, tilt toward it like a set of congregants who keep forgiving the sermon. I put on shoes because the day is a door that won’t open unless you knock with your feet, and I go to June’s to check the way her cast sits with her arm, the way the apartment sits with this new season. I bring a small bag of groceries, things that can be eaten with one hand, sandwiches that resemble strategy, a handful of nectarines because softness should be scheduled.

June has learned the weight of the cast the way you learn the weight of a new truth, by constantly bumping into it. She has tied a dish towel at the crook of her elbow like a flag that announces her left side is under construction. There is a bruise traveling down from the cut on her eyebrow like a river that decided to leave the mountain and visit the valley, and her face contains both apology and triumph, which is to say the day contains both of us. We practice the choreography of lowering and raising; we fold blankets like we have become our own grandparents. The wheel in the garage hums every time someone opens the back door, and I feel the itch in June’s fingers that cannot go the way they’re used to going. She briefs me on the cast’s personality—it hates tight sleeves, it hates door frames, it loves to be admired—and I admire it properly, from several angles, like art that might be a weapon. “Wait until it itches,” she says, a future tense that steals my breath for a second, because there is a specific kind of helplessness involved in not being allowed to scratch.

At the pharmacy, the late afternoon is a line that forgets how to move. An old man holds a paper bag like a newborn bird and tells anyone who will listen that he stopped eating grapefruit after it tried to assassinate his blood pressure. The clerk calls out names like a teacher taking attendance on the first day. I look down at the floor tiles and realize they are not straight and then cannot unsee it. When it’s my turn the bass clarinet hands me June’s orange bottles like they are trophies I won for endurance. I buy a cheap bouquet for the small victory of it and debate the greeting cards because there isn’t a category called “Congratulations on surviving someone else’s mistake, also you are breathtaking with a bruise.” I settle for blank and fill it with lines I will cross out three times before letting them live, and a drawing of a cast with a halo because sanctifying the inconvenient is a family sport.

That night I do a short set in a room that doesn’t pretend to be anything but a room with a microphone. There are twelve people including the bartender and a woman knitting something that will save ankles in winter. I think about trying the bit about hospitals—the way the monitors flirt with you and how every paper cup feels like a promise you can keep—but the words wear bandages in my mouth and I don’t have the right scissors. I stay with QuikTrip and the giant cross and the way we merge like we are practicing for a group project, and the laughs come in that tender middle register that means people have brought their hearts with them and are not pretending to sit with their coats. Afterward a man with hands like windshield wipers says his wife was in SAINT FRANCIS last month and he liked the eggs there, and I tell him I’m adding hospital egg reviews to my set, and he says I better not because food service sued his niece once, and we both smile like we’re new to language.

When I get to June’s, there is a blue bowl on the coffee table with a note under it that reads, “Prototype for yours. Not heavy enough yet.” The bowl wobbles slightly when I touch it, like it remembers when it was water. June sleeps with her mouth open in a way that makes me want to guard the door. Her arm is propped on a small tower of folded towels like a princess’s mattress, and the cast is already smudged with her life—graphite, a little flour, a fingerprint from a sauce that might be tomato or courage. I sit beside her and watch whatever cooking show the remote gave me, a French woman wearing an apron like armor coaxing soup out of things that don’t want to be soup, and every time she says simmer I think of the slow anger I felt on that corner looking at the comma on the windshield unfold. I rest my hand on the couch near June’s hip in a way that is both nothing and everything, and when she stirs and croaks, “Did you get the good gum,” I hold up the pack like a miracle and she smiles in her sleep because faith is sometimes just believing the gum will arrive.

We are not good at doing nothing, but her body demands it and I am learning obedience by osmosis. The next morning we invent a routine that could qualify as sacred if we both wore better robes. I make coffee in her kitchen that insists on being too small and she eats toast like she remembers it from childhood and not from every day since. The cast makes her right-handedness obedient and bossy, and we discover that a banana is suddenly architecture. We arrange pills in a little plastic prison that says S M T W like a church marquee, and the sound they make hitting the compartments is the sound of a tiny band warming up. When she showers I stand in the hall and tell jokes to the wall because laughter is proof of life, and she calls out for the towel and I deliver it like I was born to hand people towels at the exact moment they remember they are wet. Daylight is gentle until it isn’t, and when the sun shifts into interrogator mode we close the blinds halfway and make our lives happen in that municipal kind of shade.

Three days later, the town decides to test us properly. The weather radio, a small plastic loaf on June’s counter that she claims was a gift from an ex-boyfriend who believed in readiness more than pleasure, screams itself awake uninvited. The sound drills a new hole in my skull and fills it with alphabet soup—storm cell, rotation, debris signature—which is the calm way of saying the sky has remembered it can become a hand. June and I look at each other with that particular Oklahoma smile that means we both want to panic in a charming way. The phone buzzes in sync, a chorus of concern performed by towers and satellites, and somewhere not far from us the sirens begin to pull the day into a longer shape. It is not noon on a Saturday, which means everyone becomes a professional at pretending to be hydrologically literate. We do the thing we were taught in third grade: we make ourselves small, we move to the most interior of interior places, which in June’s apartment is the bathroom that has decided it is a closet’s cousin. I pile the floor with towels and quilts like we are building a fort with none of the romance and all of the intention, and June lowers herself down with that careful choreography of a person who has been assigned a temporary wing.

We sit on the tile that remembers every foot that has ever been placed upon it, and the cast becomes a white animal between us. June’s breath is too fast at first and then decides to copy mine, and there is no greater intimacy than breathing on purpose in a small room. The tub has a gray ring we both ignore because who we are in a storm is not who we are in a magazine. I hold my phone like a compass and tell her what the weatherman is telling me in a voice trained to be kind to frightened animals: the rotation is north, the rotation is east, the rotation is messing with the people who decided to live near that old industrial park. We remember out loud how we learned to put our backs to glass, how cafeteria ladies herded us like their most fragile breads, how the school janitor opened the door to the boiler room and became for five minutes a priest. June says she could kill for a pretzel and I say if the building remains, I will take this as a commandment and not a preference, and she laughs in the little hiccup way her laugh goes when her body is trying to participate and I want to cry because the sound is a diagnosis I can live with.

The storm doesn’t visit our block in the way that creates new roofs, but it drags its fingernails across enough neighborhoods that the sirens argue with each other. At one point the power stutters and we become pioneers for a minute, the glow from the phone a new kind of candle that makes us both look like rumors. June reaches for my hand without asking her hand if it’s ready, and our fingers do that embarrassing thing where they know each other faster than the rest of us does. I don’t talk for a minute because I am busy asking the tinier parts of me to behave, and we sit in the tub cave and practice not thinking about everything people in our town have lost to the sky. When the thunder moves away and the rain calms itself like a dog that has decided to accept the leash again, we don’t stand up right away. We stay until the room grows bored with our alive-ness, until June’s phone buzzes with her sister’s report from the other side of town—two fences down, one lawn chair in the neighbor’s pool, the tulips practicing resilience—and we allow ourselves to become upright animals again.

After a storm, everything outside looks like it was washed by someone who overdid it. The world shines a little too hard and the air carries that metallic smell that belongs to train tracks and adrenaline. I drive through puddles that want to be lakes and we make good on the pretzel promise at a QuikTrip that hums with second chances. The men in reflective vests are back in session, discussing hailstones like gossip, and someone has put a sign on the roller grill that says CLOSED FOR CLEANING, and the four exclamation points convince me the grill has seen things. We share a pretzel and the cheese cup glows like a campfire stubbornly refusing to go out, and June draws a heart on her cast with a Sharpie because moving ink over new surfaces is its own therapy. She writes the date of the storm in tiny engineer’s numbers and underlines it, an annotation to the week, and I think of how we’re all just margin notes pretending to be text, and I love us for it.

It doesn’t happen all at once, but our time accrues like lint in a pocket that refuses to empty. I start keeping a toothbrush at June’s in a glass that used to hold toothpicks at some party where people dipped tiny sausages into assertive sauces, and after three days it stops surprising us. We organize her medications into small stacks that look like poker we refuse to play and set phone alarms with hilarious names like BONES and HEAD and DO NOT BE A HERO. We learn the exact angle of her couch that allows her arm to be both elevated and ignored. She comes with me to the bar on a Tuesday because she says healing requires field trips. She sits at the back with her elbow perched on a small pillow she brought from home like a wealthy 1840s woman who refuses to touch a chair with bare fabric, and I tell a soft room about the way the weatherman says “tornadic” like a dessert and nobody laughs and everyone nods, and at the end a woman with a face that has done a lot of looking says, “I like the part where you said you put the furniture back,” and I realize I did say that and also that I don’t, not anymore.

At her pottery class, a group of teenagers with hands like inventions looks at June like she is both cup and kettle. She demonstrates trimming with her right hand and her voice holds all four corners of the room. Clay has never pointed out our clumsiness like this and she decides not to apologize. She tells them about centering by telling them about walking into a storm with a calm you did not pack. She asks me to stand near the splash pan and read the handout because the paper won’t stay open on its own and also because I love the part where the clay remembers its water. I watch a girl discover that her bowl wants to be a spiral and swallow a laugh that would make me unwelcome. June praises a boy’s cylinder like it is a small city learning its zoning laws and I fall in love with stability for the fifth time that afternoon.

It is not until a week later that we try the Ferris wheel again because people in small towns know not to test a machine that pretended at myth during a storm. The carnival packs up slowly, like it is sneaking out of a house that knows how to hold on. The wheel remains for the last night like a tooth the mouth is not ready to give the tooth fairy. We go on a Sunday when the church parking lots have exhaled and the air has that after-singing exhaustion. June’s cast is now a guest book; there are signatures from her niece, from the pottery kid who made his cylinder stand up straight, from my mother who wrote a verse so tiny I had to use a magnifying app and laughed myself into a better hour when I did. The man with the cash box recognizes us in the way a cash box recognizes faithfuls, and he jokes that the wheel likes apologies. We give him two tickets and promise to treat the thing like a friend’s fragile aunt, and he hands us a napkin like a talisman because sometimes napkins are all you can offer in the face of probability.

The carriage creaks in the ceremonial way it has learned from generations of creaks, and we sit side by side like conspirators who don’t know the plan yet. The wheel lifts us the way a sentence lifts its clause, and the town becomes a polite map, all its problems looking manageable from the height of pretending. I see the library’s roof, the train car, the church steeple that has figured out its angles, the brick that glows even at dusk because showmanship is a material. June points with her free hand and narrates her favorite corners as if she invented them: the place where the cat colony performs its political theater, the alley where the plant shop hides its overgrown, the rooftop where she once watched fireworks and decided to forgive her father for being the kind of man who fixes things instead of naming them. The wind finds us because it always does, and my stomach does its small mutiny, and June places her palm on the metal bar and says, “This is how I pray,” and I say, “Me too, with better lighting.”

At the top, when the wheel pauses to distribute awe, the town gives us back our names and asks what we plan to do with them. I think of the night in the hospital, the beep that kept our time, the nurse with the pearl, the plaid blanket June’s sister brought that made the bed honest. I think of the cross on the highway looking like a recipe I don’t have the oven for. I think of the heavy bowl she promised and how some vessels are engineered to require both hands, that they’re not a failure but a design. I feel the words pushing at my teeth like a crowd at a door, and I do what I always do when my body fills with sentences I can’t figure out where to place: I test one quietly. “You are my favorite unsafe thing,” I say, and it comes out wrong and right at once, a confession disguised as a koan. June turns her head not all the way, just enough to let me know she knows she has heard something, and she smiles the way a person smiles when she is translating herself for herself. “We should not raise children,” she says after a beat, and we both laugh the laugh of people who understand the gravity of their joke and also how to survive it.

We get off the ride with knees we pretend are steadier than they are, and the ground receives us like a parent who forgot to scold. The man with the cash box winks with his mustache and I decide to love him in the precise, limited way one loves cash box men. The lot smells like dust that just remembered it was a person once, and we walk to the edge of the carnival where the trailer with the cotton candy spinner hums like a grandma who knows better. June cannot eat spun sugar with a concussion according to a study I invented, so we share a lemonade that insists on its sourness and insist back with our straws. The sky gives us a dramatic gradient it did not need to give and in return we promise not to complain about the mosquitos, and the mosquitos pretend to accept this and then conduct their business anyway because nature serves its own board.

In the days that follow, the community shows up in the ways communities do when they are both deeply themselves and accidentally holy. The church ladies bring a casserole with a topography that suggests the presence of Doritos, and my mother insists on staying to do the dishes because the dishes are the only liturgy she trusts. The neighbor on June’s right whose name changes every time she tells it knocks to borrow a cup of flour and leaves with a loaf of bread she baked last week because she thinks the act of giving is a loop. The man who watched the accident calls to ask if June needs someone to mow and refuses money because he says gratitude is currency enough though I know he would not refuse a pie. The kids at the pottery studio present June with a gift: a small ceramic plaque that reads YOU ARE A BOWL WITH HANDS, and the S is backward, and I cry in the bathroom because they have accidentally written scripture.

Onstage, I try the hospital bit again with a small amendment: I mention the way the registrar asked for “relationship” and how the word felt like standing outside a club without the right shoes. I say friend because that is the ticket that lets me in, and I make a joke about how English is a cheap landlord sometimes, and the room laughs in the good way, the way you laugh when you recognize your own lease. I talk about the sirens and how we all become furniture at once, how bravery here is holding very still and letting the storm write its bad poem without us in it. I talk about bowls that make you use both hands and a town that only looks small from the outside, and I realize halfway through that I am trying to talk the shape of my love into language that won’t scare it away. June sits at the back with her elbow on that pillow like a monarch with humble tendencies and her laugh does the thing I pray for, that crack in the middle that lets the room through, and I hold the mic like a barn handle again, like the door to a better self might slide open if I am gentle.

One afternoon my father appears with a drill he pretends is a passport. He has decided June needs a shelf near her couch because books should come to you when you can’t go to them, and he eyes the wall with the suspicion he saves for anything that claims to be load-bearing without proof. He finds studs like a conjurer and the shelf rises out of the drywall like a lesson. He shows June how to rest the weight of hardcovers with a cast, and she shows him how clay dries faster in this heat if you turn the pieces, and the two of them nod at each other like a handshake between species. My mother brings a jar of soup that is so exactly soup that I want to write it a thank you card, and she leaves notes in June’s cabinets that say LEFT and RIGHT because she thinks it’s funny to prank the future. When my parents leave they stand in the parking lot waving like people who invented waving, and June says, “Sometimes I forget to envy you,” and I say, “Sometimes I forget to deserve them,” and we let the evening be a neutral witness.

There is a day when June tries to put her hair in a ponytail one-handed and fails gracelessly and throws the elastic across the room with the zeal of an athlete who wants the joy but hates the sport. I retrieve it and stand behind her and gather her hair in my hands like it is a handful of creek water, and I tell my fingers to remember how to be kind. The elastic goes around twice and the third time is stubborn and I pull it with my teeth and we both stop breathing because that is the kind of intimacy even television refuses to film, and then it is done and her hair is in a silly loop that makes her look like a girl in a photo booth who made a face right before the flash. She turns and the thank you between us is louder than is polite, and I stand very still because motion would be dangerous manipulation. We do not kiss because we are both cowards and archivists; we catalogue the wanting and set it on the shelf my father hung and step away like responsible curators.

By the time the cast begins to itch, our lives have braided in ways that feel like they were always meant to. We have rules we never wrote down: if one of us says “library,” the other one puts on shoes; if one of us says “Ron,” the other one must concoct a theory about men who assemble rides in shorts; if one of us says “sirens,” the other one says “bathroom,” and we meet there with a quilt and a joke. The bowl June promised begins to take form again under her right hand, assisted by an unpaid assistant with two clumsy ones, and I learn the subtle pressure of supporting without reshaping. She calls the bowl mine out loud and I hear the word like a small bell I could marry. It is heavier this time, on purpose, and when she lifts it to the bat to be carried to the shelf, her elbow asks for help and my hands arrive without a permission slip. The act of carrying becomes a pronoun. The kiln will finish what we cannot, and when it comes out I know I will hold it with both hands, on stage, in kitchens, at QuikTrip tables that pretend to be black tile, and I will talk about how some loves require more of your surface area, how some towns teach you to grip the railing with your words, and how sometimes the ride becomes the point instead of the scenery.

At night, when sleep tries to flirt and fails, I walk. I walk past the plant shop where the owner has started leaving little notes under the pots like fortunes you can water. I walk past the mural with the roses and the word LOVE and I allow myself to think the L is for Learn and the O for Offer and the V for Velocity and the E for Enough, and I know this is sentimental in a way I would mock on stage and I do not care. I walk to the church where my mother sings, and the choir is rehearsing with the door cracked, and my mother’s alto slides through the night like a spoon through cake. I walk to the place where June’s car learned to reconsider and stand for a minute and let the shadow of a streetlamp run over my shoes, and I do not cry because the asphalt does not deserve the salt. I walk home and make notes on paper that already has notes, and I practice saying the thing out loud to a chair because furniture is safe. I try the sentence “I love you” and it fits and does not fit and the hinge of my jaw considers leaving me and then decides to stay.

On a Monday morning that looks like it was ironed, I teach June how to tie a scarf one-handed because there is a show she wants to go to in Tulsa and she refuses to be unfinished. She stands in the mirror and I stand behind her doing the kind of math you can only do with fabric, and the knot sits at her throat like gratitude. We get in my car and the BA Expressway is merciful, and the giant cross plays nice and the sky minds its own enormous business. We meet a friend of hers at a gallery that used to be an autoshop and I stand in front of paintings of landscapes that are too honest to be pretty and try to breathe in art like it’s a vitamin. On the drive back we don’t talk for a long time because sometimes silence is the only word that fits and I am trying not to narrate our lives so hard that I miss living them. At a red light, June says, “We are a bowl with hands,” and I say, “We are a bowl with hands,” and we grin at the windshield like it is an accomplice, and then the light changes and the world, obedient and wild, moves forward.By the time the cast itches into its own personality, we are in chapter five of the summer in the way you can feel a song move into its bridge without anyone telling you. The bruise over June’s eye ripens into the kind of yellow you only see on ceramic glazes with names like cornfield and vintage lemon, and strangers have stopped giving her the soft sympathy eyes and moved into the stage where they tell her about their cousin who once broke three bones at once but still went to work the next day, like cruelty is a loyalty program you can join. She takes to carrying a wooden spoon to slide under the cotton when the itch becomes a theology, and we negotiate with it like diplomats who know the other side’s demands are just a rattier version of ours. I mark dates on a wall calendar I’ve brought over because my phone can’t handle the gravity of recovery, and the boxes fill with appointments that have either urgency or theater depending on the time of day, and we build our week around the saw that will free her arm like a magician who promises to put the lady back together. The days are the long lake kind, lying out in front of us pretending to be wider than they are, and we learn to put a small boat on them and not overthink whether we packed oars.

The bowl comes out of the kiln on a Tuesday morning that smells like a joke about coffee and repentance. We are at the studio before the door wants to open because anticipation is an alarm that requires no snooze button, and June’s right hand is a compass needle that keeps returning to the shelf where the owner stacks work like sleeping cats. The bowl is on the second tier-—of course it is—-sitting like it knew we’d make it late if it sat any higher, and it is a color the glaze chart calls river, which feels like flattery to both water and bowl. It is heavy in my palms in the way a choice is heavy and it throws its shadow honestly, and the base has that slight rise like it remembers it was once wheel and air. There is a small crack that decided to be decorative instead of destructive and I say out loud, like a charm, that integrity is a spectrum and not a score, and June grins that dangerous grin that has gotten me through winters. She runs her fingers along the rim with the care of a person petting a skittish animal, and the bowl accepts us with the dignity of something that knows it will be useful even if we decide to worship it by accident. We write my name and the date in small letters on the underside because everything that wants to survive our houses needs archiving, and when I lift it with both hands the bowl nods, like, yes, this is the exact agreement we made.

The removal room at the orthopedist’s office is bright in the way new money is bright, and there is a poster of a skeleton mid-salsa as if bone health is a party you forgot to RSVP to. The saw is a friendly horror, the tech assures us, and he demonstrates on a piece of foam the way it refuses to bite a balloon, and I cannot imagine a job where your day is convincing people you will not carve them like a ham. June laughs with her mouth and not her eyes because endurance has stages, and when the blade meets the cast it makes a sound like summer cicadas gossiping and the dust that puffs up smells like every chalkboard I ever wanted to apologize to. Underneath her arm is a pale strange cousin of her arm with hair pressed into a wave like an old-timey man’s comb-over, and the skin has a map’s sincerity, and the tech says it looks great and we believe him because he has been hired by reassurance. He tells us about PT like it’s a party favor you earn, and he hands June a squeeze ball the color of a sin she would never commit, and on the drive home she flexes her fingers like she’s practicing a chord and we both clap for different reasons at the red lights.

I book Tulsa on a whim and a dare because a comedian I respect texts me that he has a slot if I’m willing to drive forty minutes and pretend not to mind that the room is an old fire station that forgot to retire. June insists on coming even though I offer her a night of television that requires no posture, and we take the BA Expressway like we are auditioning for a map. The cross at the megachurch exit glows like a GPS for sinners, and I want to be annoyed but I also want to be guided, and I make a note to write a bit about religious signage being the original billboards. Tulsa sidles into us with its art deco and its bridges that look like they studied abroad, and the room turns out to be exactly as weird as promised, with hoses coiled like snakes in the corners and a vintage call box on the wall that pings occasionally like it’s trying to bring ghosts to the show. I do the new hospital run and it lands in me while it lands in them, and the line about “relationship” gets a groan-laugh that is the sound of people seeing their own paperwork. June sits back left with a ginger ale like it’s a contract and nods on the parts where I’m trying to slide a feeling past my own bouncer, and after, the host tells me I found a gear he’s been waiting for me to find. The drive home is one of those nocturnes where the tail lights make a parade we didn’t know we needed, and in the dark June says she keeps thinking about the man who ran into traffic for her and whether he told the story when he got home, and I say maybe he doesn’t tell stories, maybe he just makes shelves, and she makes a small sound like agreement and I want to put my hand on her thigh and mark the moment and don’t.

My mother invites us to the church potluck with a voice that could sell real estate in heaven, and I say yes because saying yes to the women with crockpots feels like banking favor for the future. We bring the heavy bowl because it demands to be tested by starches, and June carries it in both hands like a mother walking a child to the first day of school. The fellowship hall smells like cumin and resurrection and the table is a timeline of Oklahoma casseroles from Dorito to discipline, and my mother greets June with the exact amount of gentle a person requires when introducing a bruise to a room full of opinions. June tells the choir ladies that the bowl was a collaboration because she’s a generous liar, and they coo over it like it might recite Corinthians if asked. I stand with a plastic fork and listen to Sister Evelyn explain why she refuses to list mayo as an ingredient on index cards because some people don’t need the whole truth, and I wonder if my whole career is just a long argument with that sentence. When the men from the deacon board lift tables in that choreographed way men in their seventies lift tables, June’s eyes go soft and I know she is missing a father she has not fully forgiven, and I turn and ask my own father to tell the story about the time he put a ceiling fan in backwards so it pulled air up instead of down, because nothing fixes the present like putting a fan on it.

June’s ex-boyfriend appears like weather one afternoon in the form of a text with the subject line “Are you okay,” which is what men write when they want to seem as if they have learned a new language and are still using the old alphabet. She reads it out loud to me in the kitchen while her coffee maker hiccups and I stare at the ceiling crack that looks exactly like a river delta and try to decide whether to be generous or strategic. He is the weather radio guy, the one who believed in go-bags and joked about earthquakes in a state that preferred its disasters visible, and he was not cruel but he was the wrong size for her life, and she replies politely and I cannot tell if the politeness is literal or a mask.
