After she presses send she taps the counter twice with the fingernail of her right index finger, an old June tic that means she did something brave and will probably need an aspirin for it later. I want to say things like I am here and also I am not him and I am not a plan, but the coffee is making its slow argument for patience and I decide instead to rinse the blueberries in our bowl and place them in front of her like a thesis.

We host a garage sale not because we need the money but because the objects have begun to whisper and their gossip is exhausting. June sets up a table with cups that failed their interviews and I arrange a neat grid of books I insist I’m ready to let go of and then move three to a private pile like I’m saving soldiers during a draft. The neighborhood arrives in shorts with small bills like hope, and a woman with a toddler buys a chipped mug and tells June she likes the way the chip makes her feel invited to be imperfect, and I watch June’s eyes do the exact thing they do when she thinks about teaching. A teenage boy hovers over a set of measuring spoons for long enough that I finally say, “You a baker,” and he says “I want to be,” like what he wants is a rebellion, and I throw the spoons in for free because the future deserves good tools. We put out a tip jar that says Hospital Humor Fund because clarity sells, and by noon it is full of wrinkled cash in the way churches like, and we count it together on the workbench while the wheel in the corner pretends not to watch. June writes THANK YOU on a piece of cardboard in her neat right-handed teacher script and tapes it to the garage door, and I have to swallow twice before I can say anything normal because gratitude is a spice that burns if you breathe it too fast.

Onstage, I discover a new timing in a joke about the BA Expressway that makes me feel like I moved a couch to the other wall and the room grew a window. I talk about how merging here is a ritual of consent and how your turn signal is a half-prayer, and a man in a hat shaped like an apology laughs so hard he slaps the table and I forgive him for previously looking bored. I add a bit about hospital eggs versus church potluck deviled eggs and the comparison makes me a little nervous because I have taught myself to keep my mother’s name and mayonnaise out of the same sentence, and she laughs when I tell her later and tells me to add paprika because audiences like color. June sits with both hands around a cup of ice water in a posture that would look like fear if you didn’t know her, and she tilts her head when I hit the line about paperwork that decides if your love counts and I think I will die if she doesn’t get it and I think I will die if she does. After the show a woman with a cardigan counting as a personality corners me at the bathroom sinks and tells me her girlfriend wasn’t listed on a form once and so she didn’t get a call, and I hold her hand while the faucet runs like an organ and promise her I will say the word girlfriend on stage like it is ordinary until it is.

We take a Thursday field trip to the Blue Whale in Catoosa because the internet told us it is the kind of roadside that makes memory behave, and because neither of us has a hobby that involves bats. The whale sits in the pond like someone’s good idea escaped its tank, and its painted smile is less cheerful up close, the way a clown is always mostly paint. Children climb its spine with the reverence of pirates who paid admission, and a man in a gimme cap reads the plaque out loud like a poem. June stands on the little dock and leans on the rail with her good elbow and I can feel the childhood in her body, the nine-year-old who wanted to be both astronaut and potter and did not understand that both professions have a lot of cleaning involved. We walk through the whale’s stomach and it is both gross and sacred, and I put my palm against the metal rib and feel the morning’s heat stored there like a secret. At the gift stand we buy a sticker that says OKLAHOMA LOVES YOU MORE THAN YOU DESERVE and put it on the back of June’s weather radio because we are tired of letting practicality be humorless. On the ride home we drive slow on purpose, the way you do when the day is a good dog, and we stop at a farm stand for peaches and the woman taking money calls us “you girls” and for once it feels less like an erasure and more like an inheritance we can edit.

A new student named Ava shows up at June’s pottery class with a face that has been given too many instructions and hands that disobeyed them. She is thirteen in the posture way, head thrust forward like a turtle wearing a crown, and her grandmother waits in a folding chair with a paperback and the concentration of a saint. Ava wedges like she has an argument with the clay that began in another room, and June places her right hand over Ava’s left to change the angle and it is such a simple miracle that I want to call a reporter. The wheel turns and the spiral remembers it is a spiral, and Ava’s breath evens like a machine learning a song, and when the cylinder climbs up like it wants to see out the window the girl’s whole face becomes an event. Later, when the room smells like damp coin adding up to a future, June tells the class to put their names on the bottoms of their pieces and I watch fourteen kids claim the underside, and I feel my chest do that thing again, the widening that always precedes a new bit and a new admission. After class, Ava lingers to ask if she can make something heavy on purpose, and June says, yes, the world requires it and I say, yes, and so do hands.

The first day we try to run again, it is not actual running, it is the negotiation two women in their thirties have with gravity when one of them has a recently freed radius and the other one has spent the last weeks learning how to be more chair than person. We go to the park where the track loops like a sentence that forgot to end, and we jog in a way that would disappoint any coach, and we applaud ourselves like the crowd you hire for morale. The teenagers in soccer camps slide past as if powered by certainties we no longer own, and the men with early retirements walk in pairs discussing boats they do not intend to purchase, and the geese are geese because nothing we do changes that. June’s breath does the thing it did in the bathroom during the storm, copying mine until it finds its own rhythm, and the sun lowers like it has done this before and will do it again whether or not we participate. On lap two June says, “I think my arm misses being called a wing,” and I say, “I have never not called it that,” and she smiles without looking at me because looking would knock both of us off our line. We finish sweaty and very proud of nothing and sit on the curb to praise our knees and text my mother “We exercised” and she responds with three clapping hands and a link to an article about hydration that I do not open out of respect.

The people who play trivia at the bar on Wednesdays have started calling me “the tornado girl,” which is either a brand or a warning, and I lean into it like a porch in high wind. The host insists on music rounds that are mostly heartbreak disguised as choruses, and June writes our team name as Bowl With Hands even when the bartender mispronounces it on purpose, and every time I nail an answer about a 90s pop star I feel like I’m a citizen again. There is a table of guys who work roofs and guess every sports question with confidence, and once when the storm sirens hiccup outside of schedule, one of them says, “False alarm,” without checking his phone, and I am both jealous and tender with the ease of his certainty. We win a $25 tab one week because I recognize a picture of a particular rumpled British author whose books smell like dust and decisions, and we buy onion rings like we’re in a movie, and when the plate arrives June laughs because the onion rings are stacked in a useless tower, and I make a joke about architecture in poor neighborhoods, and the bartender shakes his head at me like he paid for my upbringing and wants a refund.

One evening, after a late show where the audience behaved like a seated storm, I go home to find a note slid under my door in June’s handwriting that says, “Blueberries are not currently on sale but I bought them anyway,” and below it, a drawing of the bowl with an arrow pointing to its heavy and the words both hands. She has left the blueberries on my counter in a brown paper bag that has lived other lives, and I wash them in the quiet of my kitchen while the crickets pattern their night outside and the highway hums like an appliance you cannot unplug. The bowl sits on my table like a thought I’m ready to think, and I pour the fruit in and they make a sound that reminds me of the way rain sometimes confesses on roofs, and I carry the bowl to the couch with both hands and set it down like a ceremony I didn’t know I was licensed to perform. I eat until my mouth argues with my ambitions, and I write until my wrist complains, and I fall asleep without telling anyone, which is either progress or exhaustion.

The next morning the laundromat becomes an odd church where people pray by sorting. I go because my building’s machines decided to become fountains, and June comes because she says she misses being bored in public without guilt. The place is a museum of cycles and strangers’ socks, and the woman who runs it has a sign taped to the change machine that says NO SACRED OBJECTS and I spend too long wondering what happened to make that necessary. We fold together in near silence because we are ordinary in this room and it is delicious, and I teach June the fold my mother taught me that makes T-shirts behave and she teaches me the fold someone on the internet taught her that makes fitted sheets give up. A man unfolds a sheet wider than any argument and drapes it over his shoulders like a river, and outside the sky flexes its clouds and then decides to keep the day nice, and everything is so aggressively fine I have to pinch my thigh to keep from crying.

When the local library asks me to host an open mic for their banned books fundraiser, I say yes like I’m being asked to hold a baby, and June says she will help if she can be in charge of seating because she wants to put people next to people who need each other. The library at night is a different animal, all spines and secrets, and the teens who come to read are more brave than anyone I’ve ever put on a stage in a bar. A kid in a denim vest reads a poem about a yard sign war on her block and a man in his sixties reads a passage from a novel about joy like he’s admitting an affair, and June rearranges chairs between readers like she’s officiating marriages. We pass the heavy bowl with index cards and pens and ask the room to write down a book they needed at the exact moment they weren’t supposed to read it, and people write titles like contraband and slip them into the bowl like communion, and I decide to sleep with it next to my bed like a relic. After, the librarian with the hair that could defeat a tyrant thanks us both and whispers that the city council is easier when you bring snacks, and June whispers back that we can be weapons and wait staff, and I fall a little more in love with public spaces and a lot more with the person who moves through them like she invented public.

I help June build a website because the kids at the studio are asking for class schedules in a tone that indicates the future expects to be able to click things. We sit at her dining table that is really just an altar to unthreatening groceries, and I try to make words like lip and foot and slip sound like invitations rather than jargon. She frowns at fonts like a general inspecting troops and chooses one that doesn’t look like it will cheat on us, and we take photos of the bowl on every surface in the apartment until we learn that sunlight through that one slat of the blinds is our best cinematographer. We argue about whether to use the word shop or store, and it feels like naming a child, and we settle on shop because it asks for hands. When we publish, the internet responds the way a pond responds to a pebble, with rings that may or may not hit a shore we know, and that night a woman from Nebraska orders two cups like a dare and leaves a note that says, “For my daughters, for their hands,” and June reads it three times and then once more for the part of her that doesn’t read, and I sit there with my cheek on the table because I don’t know how to hold this inside my head.

At a family dinner where my father grills chicken like he’s cross-examining it, my mother asks a question without attaching a verb to it and everyone looks at me. The question is June and me and the room is soup and my reply is a posture, and I say that I am collecting all the words for something you can hold with both hands and that none of them are short. My sister, who likes to deliver mercy with a joke, says, “I told you she would make it a paragraph,” and my father brings out the level from somewhere and says, “Whatever you say, let it be straight,” and my mother says, “Or true,” and June reaches for the roasted corn and pretends she is not the weather. Later, on the porch, while the neighborhood kids run a water hose like a government, June leans on the rail and says, “I am not a secret,” and I say, “I don’t have the stomach for secrets,” and we watch my parents pass a dish to each other with an ease you can’t counterfeit, and I feel a small click in my chest, the sound of a hinge deciding which way it wants to swing.

When the tulsa comic asks me to open for him on a weekend in August at a club that used to be a theater that used to be a church, I say yes because, honestly, where else am I going to learn to handle ghosts. The room is the kind that eats sound for breakfast, and the greenroom smells like murals and ambition, and I stand backstage with my hand on a curtain that has probably listened to better people and ask it to be gentle. June squeezes my arm where the muscle has been quietly building a case for itself, and I go out into heat and light and my breath does not leave me for once, it stays and behaves, and time and I enter into a contract we both sign. I talk about bowls and both hands and paperwork and sirens and the BA Expressway like it is a personality test we are all failing in the exact same way, and the laughter that comes back is organized and kind, a democracy of noise that puts me in office for fifteen minutes. After, when we drive home and the cross pretends to be only architecture, we don’t turn the radio on and we don’t talk because the night is a glass you should not touch until it has stopped ringing, and I think, very carefully, that I am almost brave enough to say the thing and not ask the room to forgive me.

It happens in a kitchen because of course it does. June is cutting tomatoes with her careful right hand and I am pretending not to be terrified of the knife like everyone else who has ever loved a person, and the bowl is on the counter holding cilantro with the kind of dignity herbs don’t often get. The window is sweating, the way windows sweat when the outside is training for its own Olympics, and the radio is listing ingredients in a recipe neither of us will attempt. I say her name just to see how it feels in the moment right before I set something down and she says yes without looking up because we have earned that shorthand. I say, “I love you,” in the voice I use for weather reports—measured, precise, respectful of the sky’s autonomy—because I refuse to hand something this serious over to drama, and the words are a bowl I have to lift with both hands. June sets the knife down the way people in movies set down guns, and she looks at me full-on like I’m a painting she paid for, and then she leans her hip into the counter in the subtle way she leaves room for everything she cannot control. She says, “Thank you,” first, which should have gutted me and instead stitched something, and then she says, “Me too,” and it isn’t poetry and it doesn’t need to be because we were never going to engrave it on a ring. We stand there with the tomatoes thinking about oxygen and how ridiculous it is that we’ve been doing it right all along, and then she says, “No single-serve,” and I say, “Both hands,” and we laugh because we do not know how to stop, and the cilantro is triumphant and the window fogs up because the room finally got interesting.

We do not turn into other people because that would be disrespectful to the ones who got us here. We still go to QuikTrip and run into the men in reflective vests and haggle over pretzel salt as if we had not recently restructured our entire shared dictionary. We still stop at the plant shop window to admire a snake plant that knows how to survive neglect and we still talk about storms like they’re relatives who might show up with their luggage. We still carry the bowl with both hands and we still make our beds on days when no one is visiting because dignity is a weekday habit. When the sirens test at noon on Saturday, we put our backs to the glass because some rituals deserve repeating even when the weather is on our side, and we let the howl move through us like a choir we didn’t practice for and still somehow know. We are a bowl with hands and a town with a Ferris wheel and a cross that can’t decide and a QuikTrip that keeps the lights on for anyone who can’t sleep, and the line between safe and brave is the place we stand, together, with our elbows on the small tables that would float away if we didn’t.The word girlfriend behaves differently in your mouth depending on the room you hand it to. At the urgent care clinic set up in the pharmacy after the city council forgot to approve a real flu shot budget, the clipboard offers me the tiny blank next to “relationship to patient,” and the nurse, who wears her hair in a ponytail that could double as a weapon, looks at me the way people look at checkers pieces—are you going to move diagonally or not. I circle partner because it sounds like we could open a feed store if comedy goes feral, and when the nurse reads it back she does so as if she’s taste-testing a spice she might introduce to her church chili. June sits on the folding chair with her sleeve rolled up, the bruise at her elbow the exact color of a defiant pear, and when the shot goes in she closes her eyes and breathes like she’s on the wheel, and afterward we stand together at the free cookie table eating small sugar circles like we survived something bigger than a needle. On the way out, a man stopping by for antihistamines tells his wife loudly that the word partner is for people who run construction companies, and June takes my hand with her new right to take it and says, “Construction it is,” and we walk to the car feeling like we have been issued hard hats we can decorate later.

The days lean into September the way a person leans into a screen door to hear more neighborhood. Heat holds on like a politician who doesn’t know when to retire, and the brick on Main carries it around like a story it can’t stop telling. The Ferris wheel has moved on in the same stealthy way heartbreak pretends it has, leaving behind a ring of ground that is both pressed and puffed, evidence of temporary joy. The Rose District starts to make early fall noises—cider stands rehearsing, the plant shop bringing pumpkins to the front like new babies, school bands dragging their tubas and their faith down the street on Thursday nights. I am doing a set outside for an event someone calls an artisan night, which means soft jewelry and hard opinions, and my mic is a battery-operated stick that makes my voice sound like it couldn’t wrestle a paper bag, but the crowd is willing to negotiate. June’s table is a small bright republic of cups and bowls and one single platter that looks like a lake you could win at a fair, and when people ask if the heavy bowl is a gimmick she says, “No, it’s a thesis,” and I watch the way they nod like they’ve always been hungry for a thesis they could set on their table.

We discover quickly that loving someone with two hands also means asking for their permission with two hands, left and right, comedian and civilian. The first time I tell a joke that belongs too much to June and not enough to the plank we agreed on, she catches it in the back of the room with her eyelids and sets it down gently like it’s a grasshopper that wandered onto the wrong sidewalk. The line is about the day she couldn’t wash her hair with one arm and I had to use my teeth to pull the elastic, and it gets a laugh that feels like people finding a secret door, and after the set we walk silently to the parking lot where the asphalt keeps receipts. She leans against her Camry and the comma in the windshield has settled into a clause, and she says, “That’s mine,” not like a reprimand but like a reminder of inventory. I say, “You’re right,” and I feel the small warm shame that comes when you take a cookie without asking even though the person baking them loves you and would have said yes. We stand there and edit out loud, finding the way to tell a truth without stealing it, and when we’re done, we go to QuikTrip and share a soda like teenagers who both know how to drive but insist on walking each other to the door anyway.

In my mother’s house the phrase “We will be in the fellowship hall” means many things that are not a room where you eat, and this time it means we are eating because they are celebrating the choir director’s retirement after forty-two years of telling altos not to chew their words. June arrives with the heavy bowl full of roasted sweet potatoes and rosemary, and the deviled eggs part for it like a sea with paprika, and the sound my mother makes when she sees June carrying it is the soft bell of a woman whose prayer got a tangible answer. Sister Evelyn, who runs the potluck like a benevolent judge, takes June by the elbow and introduces her to anyone who is not already a citizen of our specific universe, and I watch the way June’s face practices warmth in a new dialect, a small-town hospitality that knows how to love people it can find. My father insists on showing her the shelf he hung in the church library for the mystery paperbacks that multiply like rabbits and gives her his level to hold while he points at the wall, which is masculine flirting where I’m from, and she stands there balancing the instrument like she’s prepared to administer sacraments to the drywall. After dish duty, which is the rite by which all my relationships are measured, my mother says quietly, “I like your construction,” and she squeezes my shoulder in a way the Lord never learned to do in painting.

We decide that if we can carry a bowl together we can carry a couch together, which is a lie two lesbians made famous and I am a fan of tradition. The couch I have is a gray that admits defeat every time you look at it, and we find a used one online from a woman who writes, “It did not betray us,” which is the kind of résumé I am immediately attracted to. It is the color of oatmeal made by an ambitious hotel and the shape of a nap, and it lives temporarily on a second-floor balcony because the woman’s boyfriend has a grudge against stairs. We recruit three neighbors with the promise of pizza and the guarantee that I will find a bit about this that makes them look better than they are, and together we perform the ballet of furniture removal that involves more yelling about angles than anyone wanted. The couch scolds the stairwell with its corners and my hands discover muscles I only use when I have to argue with geometry, and when we finally get it into my living room it looks smaller, the way victory does when it sits down. We put the heavy bowl on the coffee table like a cornerstone and order too much pizza because hunger is a bully, and we eat on paper plates that have been raised to believe they are enough.

Because we are in Oklahoma and the sky has a flair for drama, there is a fall morning where the air is sly and polite and the news says frost like it’s a guest we should prepare for. June wants to see the tall grass before it gives up, so we drive to the Wichita Mountains in a car that has learned to trust us. The land there looks like the earth has knuckles and the wind has opinions, and every boulder is an elder with secrets about buffalo and park rangers and teenagers who chose their locations badly. We hike in the manner of two people who have watched other people hike and believe it involves the same muscles as continuous storytelling, and the path is stubborn but fair. At a lookout that looks out over a small lake pretending to be a god, we spread a towel and eat peanut butter sandwiches like people whose vows include crunchy, and I can see the way June’s shoulders unclench in front of that horizon. She tells me a story about her father teaching her to throw a softball that sounds like teaching and grief braided tight, and I tell her a story about my mother’s whistle, the one that could call me across three blocks and four sins, and we discover our childhoods might have been neighbors if not geographically then in the way they made us pack snacks. On the way home, we pull over at a stand that claims to have the best peach ice cream on this side of the county line, and because I have lived long enough to know that disputes about county lines are mortal, we buy two cones and eat them too fast and look like we’ve kissed a sugar ghost.

October brings a small invitation and a larger radius. A club in Oklahoma City that used to be a Methodist church and then was a bar and now is a bar that remembers it used to be a church asks me to do fifteen minutes in front of a headliner who has an album that once helped me survive a February. The room is beautiful in the way they don’t let rooms be anymore, high windows and echoes that have hugged hymns, and I stand backstage doing the math on my breath. June wants to come but her kiln has decided to be French and temperamental and she cannot ask the other potters to babysit their own work because art is a group lie that requires time management, so she kisses my cheek like it owes her money and sends me with a lucky quarter she claims she found under the mat at work. Onstage that night time behaves well and my feet remember the places on the floor where the light forgives your face, and the bit about paperwork asking who gets to be called next carries the room like a song we all knew the chorus of before anyone taught us. After, in the greenroom that still smells like lemon pledge and performative masculinity, the headliner tells me I did not rush past the quiet and I keep the sentence in my pocket like bail money. When I get back to the car there is a text from June that only says, “Listen,” and an audio clip of her kiln firing, the low roar of it like a patient machine, and I sit in the driver’s seat and play it twice and then a third time for the part of me that still doesn’t think I deserve sounds that exact.

Our first fight chooses a Tuesday because Tuesdays believe in themselves. It begins with a plant dying, which is the most lesbian way to begin anything outside a U-Haul contract. The snake plant in June’s window decides that despite its reputation for surviving neglect and conversation about neglect, it will make a point by slumping theatrically. June blames herself with a precision that would impress a jury, and I come in too quickly with jokes about resiliency that sound brave in a bar and condescending in a kitchen. She looks at me like the table suddenly grew an edge, and she says that not every wound wants a laugh, and I say defensively that laughing is how I get the air in, and she says that sometimes I suck the air out, and we stare at each other across the poor plant like two countries who forgot where they drew the border. We do the polite thing, which is to go quiet and cut vegetables and wash knives, and our quiet has elbows. The apology happens at the laundromat because the laundromat refuses to let anyone keep a grudge when the dryers are involved, and I say I am sorry in the language of switching clothes without losing socks and she says she is tired as if tiredness were a sin, and we load a machine and make an altar out of quarters, and when our towels emerge from the heat they are warm enough to change the conversation. The snake plant gets repotted with a mix of soil the internet told us to trust, and it stands mildly improved in its new home, and we decide we will not name it because we are not gods, despite evidence to the contrary.

The library hosts a zine-making workshop in a conference room that during the day contains six quiet men pretending to study the classifieds, and we go because the flyer taped to the circulation desk has a picture of scissors that looks like joy. A group of teenagers whose hair communicates in languages we never learned arrive with backpacks full of tape and conviction, and a retired art teacher named Mrs. Petty leads us with the energy of someone who still insists you wash brushes properly. We fold paper into eighths and write small manifestos about our particular corners of the city, and June writes instructions on how to center clay that would help a person get through a divorce, and I write about the exact friction at the base of the throat when you decide to tell a true thing. At the end we trade our little booklets like baseball cards and watch each other’s faces read us, and the librarian, whose cardigan has an apology stitched onto the elbow, puts out a box labeled COMMUNITY COPIES and says we can make as many as our hearts and the Xerox will let us. On our walk home, our fingers are smudged with ink and a girl on a scooter passes us like a small comet, and June says, “I forgot how much cutting-and-pasting is a spiritual practice,” and I say the internet is a zine with too many pages, and we both hum in agreement like a choir of two.

The kitchen has become our sanctuary and our lab, and the bowl is both our catechism and our experiment. We make a stew that begins with onions because everything true begins with onions, and we put the seasonings in like we’re adding adjectives to a sentence that cannot handle adverbs tonight. The heavy bowl holds the bread dough while it’s deciding whether to grow and the dough decides to be generous in a way that makes me feel personally forgiven. We eat at the table that once was a place we put mail and pamphlets from dental offices, and we set our phones in a separate room because the phones are toddlers who cannot be trusted near open flames. June tells me about a cup a student made that cracked in the kiln but did so in a way that made the damage into a line that looked designed, and I tell her about a man at the bar who apologized to me for laughing because he thinks his wife would not have liked my joke and she has been dead ten years, and we talk about how grief is a room you keep returning to even when you’ve moved. After dishes we sit on the floor and lean our heads against the couch like people in an Ikea catalogue pretending to understand minimalism, and our feet touch in a way that is both ridiculous and absolutely correct.

We invent a holiday because the calendar offered a day blank enough to be arrogant. We call it Both Hands Day and all it means is we do everything slower and require two of something before we do it. Two walks, one in the brightness and one in the bruised light. Two jokes where only one would do. Two songs the radio insists on calling classics, with two choruses each sung by two voices that are both ours. We invite my parents and June’s sister without telling them the title because they already suspect us of making new religions, and we set out two types of pie and two jugs of tea and two small bowls of salt because my mother cannot abide underseasoning even philosophically. In the late afternoon we take two cars down to the little park with the metal slide that conducts the sun like an orchestra, and we sit on two blankets while the kids make up a game with two rules, and my father and June’s sister argue amicably about which direction the wind is from using two different apps. When the light goes soft we hold the bowl in our laps at the same time because no one wrote the commandment that says you cannot, and we pass it back and forth between knees and palms like it’s teaching us something we don’t have words for yet, and we light two candles when we get home because we like the way the room looks in pairs.

I realize I have stopped apologizing for mentioning QuikTrip as if it were an embarrassing accent. We go on Thursdays at 9 like people who have a standing commitment to a church that sells pretzels and cold brew, and we watch the night students buy energy in cans and the men in reflective vests change shifts at the coffee urns with the grace of a relay team. The cashier with the eyeliner that could challenge a winged creature compliments June’s cast graffiti as if it were a permanent tattoo, and June tells her she’ll miss the attention when it’s gone, and the cashier says you’ll still have the jawline, and the banter is its own merit badge. The first time we go back after the confession in the kitchen, our mouths both do small unflattering things when we spot the table near the wall that pretends to be black tile, and when we sit down and the chair makes its unglamorous complaint, we realize that we have built a temple in a gas station and somehow the gods do not mind. We share a hot dog not because it is wise but because we are not always, and we laugh with our heads bowed and our shoulders up and the room winks with its fluorescent kindness.

The city introduces a new mural and demands our attention, which is how cities flirt. This one takes up the side of a building that used to sell wedding dresses and now sells artisanal pickles, and it is a map of Broken Arrow that refuses to be a map, all florals and coordinates hiding in the leaves. The artist is a woman with a buzz cut and a blog and she sits on the sidewalk eating a sandwich while a teenager holds a bucket and three mothers scold their children for touching even though the paint is on a wall thirty feet above their heads. We watch for a long time because watching people make things is the only reality television my soul can tolerate, and we talk about what we would draw if someone gave us a building and no reprimands. June says a row of bowls seen from above, which would look like planets that would rather be handled, and I say a long microphone cord winding through all the streets like a river of listening, and the artist comes down on her ladder to ask if we’re planning to stay all day and we say yes like weird kids in a classroom we actually liked. In the end the mural includes a small hidden Q and a small hidden T, and I text my mother a picture with the caption that she is to blame for the way we turn everything into a treasure hunt, and she sends back a heart and a recipe and a correction for a comma I forgot.

We take a road trip that isn’t to anywhere your friends would brag about on the internet because we are experimenting with a theory that satisfaction has more to do with roadside produce than vistas. We drive to a town weathered enough to be honest that has a diner called Dot’s Café where the floor tile is missing a square that the waitress refuses to get fixed because finding it is part of the experience. Dot’s has a menu that doesn’t use italics and the pancakes arrive with butter that has decided to be a sculpture, and June and I arbitrage syrup like economists trying to save a nation. On the way back we stop at a thrift store that smells like generosity and mothballs and June finds a jacket that looks like a solution, and I find a set of measuring cups that nest together like sisters who decided to be gentle this year. We pull over to watch a yard sale where a woman is selling four ceramic garden gnomes with faces like uncles and a box of VHS tapes labeled in a neat hand, “Days I Want to Remember,” and we buy neither because sometimes you get to leave the past in other people’s driveways.

The day the paperwork catches up to us doesn’t arrive with sirens or brass bands, just a letter in a window envelope that announces in its confident law firm font that we can now add each other to our emergency contacts online. We sit at the dining table like it is a court and we are both witnesses and defendants, and we type our names into a form that has the gall to ask whether we are married, and we check the box that says “domestic partner,” which is a phrase that sounds like two goats in a small wagon. We ask each other questions like middle-schoolers—favorite hospital, blood type, who to call if you can’t call me—and we answer them with a seriousness that would make our younger selves laugh and also admire us. When we hit submit, the website spins its bland little circle and then pronounces us up-to-date, and June toasts our laptops with her water glass and I cry a little bit because I am sentimental and also because the internet just made us real in a way it didn’t ask permission for. We celebrate by reorganizing the spice drawer because love is glamorous exactly when you do not expect it to be, and we argue about whether cumin belongs next to coriander or paprika, and the answer is both, which is the kind of fight we trained for.

My mother invites us to a women’s retreat that involves paper crafts and feelings, and she promises me that if I come, she will not make me sing “Oceans” with my eyes closed. The church has rented a lodge that was once a 4-H camp, and the beds are obedient and the coffee smells like hospitality reclaimed from the edge. The women I grew up watching present masculine casseroles are here in leggings and determination, and they embrace June with a warmth that would make you kinder even if you arrived rude. We sit in a circle and write letters to our former selves and then read them into a paper bag to be recycled, and I write to the girl who thought her jokes were a confession booth and tell her that sometimes you are allowed to be both priest and penitent, and June writes to the girl who thought perfection was the only way to earn peace and tells her to throw a pot that looks like a hill and call it faith. After, in the small quiet of the woods that still smell like organized trees and kid breath, my mother walks with us and tells us her own story of a friend she loved and did not know how to call friend in the right way then, and the regret sits between us like a polite dog, and we pet it and send it home. On the drive back, June says retreats are weird because everyone cries in a room where folding chairs are present and I say stand-up is the same but with beer, and we laugh like we have invented the hybrid we plan to pitch.

By the time the last warm evening gets its minute, we have built a calendar that looks less like a plan and more like a quilt. Tuesdays are comedy and teenagers molding their thumbs into cylinders, Wednesdays are trivia and onion rings stacked like a metaphor for municipal budgets, Fridays are dates that involve used bookstores and the ritual of silently dividing the dollar section, Saturdays are errands that have learned to become flirting. We fit dentist appointments and oil changes and a kiln we must babysit with chairs and crossword puzzles, and we organize our time in a way that would persuade an accountant our souls are solvent. We still fight sometimes, like the morning I forgot to refill the ice tray and June accused me of not caring about the future, which is not something you should say to a comedian who built a career out of refusing to predict outcomes, and we still make up in places that don’t deserve it, like the aisle with the laundry baskets in the big-box store that knows our car by sound. On the night the first cold front sighs into town and the BA Expressway shivers in its concrete, we stand on the balcony of my third-floor apartment and look out at the neon signs practicing endurance, and I hold the heavy bowl in my hands empty and watch the wind climb inside it like something it needs, and June leans her head on my shoulder and says, “We are weatherproof,” and I say, “We are willing,” and the crickets decide to agree because it makes their job simpler.The ice announced itself the night before like a guest who texts at 3 p.m. and says, I’m bringing three friends and one of them is loud. The weather radio lifted its little plastic throat and gave us vocabulary we didn’t want—freezing rain, accumulation, downed lines—and the men in reflective vests at QuikTrip were already stocking up on cinnamon rolls that could double as a currency. June set the heavy bowl on the counter like we were about to hold the sky and I pulled blankets from closets like my mother taught me that warmth is mostly preparation. The cats I do not own walked under parked cars like weather knows their names, and our neighborhood group chat turned into a recipe exchange for keeping pipes from having existential crises. We filled the bathtub with water because somewhere a grandmother still lives in both of us, and June taped the weather radio’s cord to the wall so it wouldn’t sulk off the counter when the power went out. The city’s trees had not yet become tuned instruments but the leaves made a sound like someone trying to remember a hymn, and I felt that small thrill you are not allowed to admit—disaster at a polite distance makes the blood behave—right before the adult part of me did a headcount of the things we might need to keep breathing.

By morning Broken Arrow wore glass. Limbs wore sleeves that changed the way light understood them and the grass blades all held their tiny swords the way a chorus might hold candles. The air picked a temperature and committed in a way most of us never do, and the first crack we heard was not thunder or gunfire but the sound of a tree forgetting how to stand. We had done the sensible things—charged, stocked, discussed, teased the idea of not being overconfident—so when the lights clicked once like they were practicing and then decided to consider other opportunities, we simply became people who know how stoves behave without electricity. June lit the burners with a match like she was proposing to them, and we balanced the heavy bowl over a simmer so the dough would pretend the world was still steady. Across the hall, Mr. Lopez swore in Spanish to a god who has learned to accept feedback, and downstairs the college kid with the aquarium knocked to ask if anyone had a generator and if the generator could love fish specifically. The hallway turned into a marketplace for extension cords, opinions and the kind of neighborly banter you only bring out when the lights are down, and I found myself standing there in boots and a sweater the color of a plan, giving the laugh I give when people need to know that I am competent and will not ask for a clipboard.

The trees turned chimes by noon. Every gust got translated into a noise someone could have patented if nature believed in paperwork, and the streetlights, sleeping and upright, looked like saints on strike. We packed a go-bag because June’s ex taught her to believe in readiness so hard she has a weather app that sends her poems, and I slid our important papers into a folder labeled FIRE in case irony wanted to play, and I put the bowl’s receipt in there too as a joke that I had to explain to myself. The church down the street announced it would become a warming center using a font that didn’t deserve that responsibility, and my mother texted a photo of the choir in coats around a piano because faith is a skill set in a power outage. We walked carefully past yards that had invented new sculptures, holding hands not because the sidewalk demanded it but because the world had shifted a quarter inch and I needed to be sure her weight was still real. The giant cross on the highway threw no shadow and looked suddenly human, a skeleton left standing when the flesh took a day off, and I wanted to tell it I understood.

Everyone knows the first thing you do after you open a warming center is find the cord that will behave like an extension of your lungs. The fellowship hall filled with the smell of instant coffee and old carpet and relief, which is the same smell in every church basement from here to wherever Jesus found bowls that big. I grabbed the mic from the youth group’s karaoke setup and spoke like I was calling us to order, which I was in a small way, and I found that my voice knew how to make instructions sound like an invitation. “Blankets along the back wall,” I said, inserting the word please because manners are a theology here, “hot drinks to the left, medical check-in near the coat racks, small people can color on the stage but no one ascends the drum kit like Moses.” People laughed with their shoulders because their mouths were busy being alive, and June started a little assembly line of cups and ladles and whispered to every person who came through like she had their biography in her pocket. My father arrived with a toolbox like a devout man brings scripture, and he fixed a radiator with stubbornness and a borrowed coin, and I watched him work the way you watch someone do a trick that has saved you before. Sister Evelyn materialized with soup you could stand a spoon in, and I declared our bowl a community asset for the afternoon, and people dipped from it with a reverence usually reserved for sacraments and margarine at holiday dinners. The sound of branches failing made us all flinch in unison twice, and by the third time we had learned to read the pauses, and I felt the room become a single creature despite its upholstery.

By evening, the city had the look of a place that had already told all its stories once today and was willing to repeat them if we asked politely. We walked back through a neighborhood rearranged by force and gravity, and it felt like the day after a wedding where the chairs are still out and the flower petals are honest about their wilt. June carried the bowl empty the way someone carries a newborn after the first bath, with both hands and a confidence that frightened me a little with its beauty. We passed a young couple trying to free a branch from a power line with the kind of plan that would have insulted a cartoon, and I made a joke and then made a better suggestion, and they asked if we had a chainsaw like asking for a spare moon. Back at the apartment the temperature had decided to be brave, and we perched candles in jars of dried beans like Pinterest refugees because necessity is very good at convincing you it invented taste. June propped her weather radio like a small angry friend near the window and I wrapped my hands around a mug that I did not need to drink from to feel hot and called my mother to hear how many gallons of chili my father thought could solve the grid. We slept under three blankets pretending to be one, and the ice popped and the trees argued and the cat I still do not own found the stairwell and sang, and June’s breath beside me recited the poem my life has been trying to write without lying.

The second day of the outage taught me a new way to count. We measured time by when the neighbor’s generator coughed and when the ice finally fell from the mailbox like it had taken a core sample of our past. The heavy bowl earned its name by holding heat from the oven we woke twice to give it concept, and we ate bread that failed upward and called it rustic because naming is a kindness. The hallway evolved into barter again and I handed out the last of our tea lights like I was officiating small marriages that would last four hours if you were lucky and shorter if you breathed too hard. On our way to check on Mr. Lopez with a thermos we baptized in the sink, we found the college kid with the aquarium in tears because he had been certain about something and the fish disagreed, and June knelt in that gentle way she has and said a prayer to the god of small lives that I believed in without needing to meet. When the power came back for an hour at noon and then left again like a boyfriend with an opinion, the entire building made a noise like we were trapped under one laugh that had to turn into a curse midway through, and I found myself telling jokes in the hallway not because it was my job but because my mouth is a machine that wants to make wheels. People sat on their thresholds in coats and we became a block party of exhaustion and good-natured complaint, and when the upstairs kid asked me if I would do my set right there I did three minutes clean and learned that jokes about ice travel well if the audience’s toes agree.

In the end it was the church who saved our freezer meat and the QuikTrip who saved our morale. When the power made its final return in the late afternoon, the sound filled the rooms like a dog tail and we all clapped, including my father on speakerphone because he claps at anything with the audacity to turn on. June and I looked at each other across the kitchen’s restored hum like people who have been told their marriage is legal in a state that previously wanted to argue, and then we looked at the clock because the warming center needed cleaning and soup bowls needed the kind of washing that constitutes a citizenry. We walked back through a neighborhood made damp and shining and a street littered with dreams that used to belong to trees, and Sister Evelyn handed me a dishrag and informed me with love that my rinsing needed to be more persuasive. The room echoed again with the long low sounds human beings make when they remember they are temporary, and I found myself humming with the dishwasher like we had a common ancestor.

The first show after the ice landed me in a packed room that had all discovered Tuesday again. The city carried a hangover and a gratitude, and you could feel it in the way we all agreed to take off our coats and believe in non-seasonal drink orders. I ran the new bit about the warming center and the mic I used like a shepherd’s crook, about the weather radio’s insistence that we think in triangles, about the hallway set where Mr. Lopez heckled me with theology and I accepted because we were all clergy that day. I did the line about the giant cross without its lighting and the way we decide to love symbols with batteries, and the laugh arrived from the good part of the room, the part that hadn’t decided yet what it wanted to be better about. June sat back left with her elbow on a pillow she’d smuggled in under her coat and smiled with that head tilt that means she’s watching the timing find itself, and when I hit the last line about both hands and the soup bowl, she let go of her breath in the way that tells me my work made a landing that I can build on. A man came up after and told me about the way his grandmother used to keep her pilot light alive with a hair dryer and faith, and I wrote the sentence down because sometimes audiences do your job for you at a level you cannot invoice.

In the quiet after the storm, the city started to ask its questions again. There were branches to haul and fences to prop and intersections to treat like conversations and the library resumed telling us what books we were late for. June’s studio became a relief center for objects, with shelves of cups that now looked like survivors and bowls that demanded a second firing as if they had not been told they were enough. I sat in the corner and did my email like a person who has learned to read a claim number as if it were a poem, and June taught a class where she described how the wheel forgives you if you forgive it first, and the teenagers wedged with the seriousness of people who have been warned wisely about their wrists. Late in the afternoon a girl named Kayla cried because the lip of her bowl won, and June put her right hand over Kayla’s left and told her that clay loves two chances, and the rest of the class exhaled in a room that held both anonymity and witnesses. I stood there with my notebook pretending to work and really just collected the words we are building a house with. It is a strange kind of intimacy to recognize the sentence you will tell a room later while it is being born in front of a sink with someone else’s sponge.

September turned to a kind of October that remembered how to be generous. The school band marched past the mural practicing for a homecoming queen who would wave like a person who knows this will be written in her bones later, and the plant shop lined up a small parade of pumpkins that had been told their names already. The city announced a harvest festival with a poster that contained too many fonts and we said we would go because we are obligated to witness our town try. June got invited to set up a table with the potters and I said yes before she could consider humility, and we spent a Friday night labeling things with small numbers that looked like they remembered being lottery tickets. The heavy bowl got its own sign that said HANDLE WITH BOTH HANDS in a font my mother would approve of and Sister Evelyn would edit, and the first person who tried to lift it with one palm realized her arm was an optimist and laughed the laugh that signals future loyalty to a craftsperson. I went on at six with the sun trying out its evening colors and a mic balanced on a stand that had seen better weddings, and I talked about bowls and hands and paperwork and sirens in front of a row of hay bales that believed in splinters, and a child yelled punch line at the wrong time and I told her there’s no wrong time for making friends with a noise. We closed our booth in the dark and counted our money the way pioneers must have counted their spoons after a rough winter, and June bought a jar of pickles from a man who insisted they would heal our relationship, and I said we have a jar for that already and it’s called talk.

A week after the ice, the city council decided to be the city council in public about art. There was an agenda item about performance permits and amplification, language that promises not to be about you until someone reads it in a tone that makes your name show up in the margins. The library sent a mass email with the subject line COMMUNITY CONVERSATION and the body of the message read like a dare from a friendly aunt, and June and I went because love is not just soup and bowls, it is also chairs and microphones and the ability to sit still in a room where some people have decided to argue with their own breath. I wore a sweater that said please but sturdier on the inside and June wore her jacket that tells the truth, and we took our seats and nodded at the people who clean our teeth and fix our shoes and teach our kids to read their own handwriting. A man stood up and asked why comedy needed to be loud, and I stood up and said my job is not to be louder than your life but to sneak inside it with permission, and a woman in a hat with a scripture embroidered around the brim asked if any of this had to do with the children, and I said all of this has to do with the children because they will inherit the room we build, and her face softened the way wheat does before it gets cut. June put her hand on my knee under the table when it was not my turn, and the head of the council rubbed his eyes in a way that said he needs more vegetables, and in the end they voted to let us keep our small noises as long as we promise not to grow up to be a stadium. We filed out with that specific exhaustion that follows civic successes that could have been failures, and on the steps we ran into the muralist eating a granola bar like a cigarette, and she nodded at us like we had pulled a nail out of her tire without asking to be mentioned in the blog.

When my grandmother’s roommate from the retirement home died, the funeral was an exercise in respect and practical hats. We drove to a chapel that has sold more tissues than space and sat with two dozen people who had known this woman’s handwriting better than her handwriting knew itself. The pastor had been assigned the eulogy in the same way people are assigned casserole duty, and he told a story about a potluck in 1987 that involved an exploding microwave and the devil’s urge for Tupperware, and we all laughed in the cleaned-up way you laugh when grief is in the room wearing socks. June squeezed my hand at the part where the pastor said the deceased was someone who preferred to return the grocery cart to the right place even when no one was looking, and I remembered the day I first pushed a cart into its corral and thought of my future self obligingly, and I cried because someone we did not know had made our sidewalks safer for those of us who would arrive later. After, in the fellowship hall, I found the guest book, a fetish item in Oklahoma, and I wrote our names and a sentence about bowls because that is what’s left of me most days, and the family thanked us with the face people wear when they wonder if the strangers in their grief belong here and then decide anyone with hands does.

The first assignment we gave ourselves after the storm was to say the word girlfriend in rooms that didn’t know whether to clap. We tried it at the pharmacy with the ponytail nurse and at the DMV where the line is a religion, and we tried it at the hardware store where my father buys screws like he is rescuing orphans, and we tried it at the church where my mother prays most of her prayers with a dust rag. Each time the word behaved differently, softened or sharpened by carpet or tile, fluorescent light or sunlight, eyebrows or none. At the plant shop, the owner got a look on her face like the pothos behind her had told her a secret, and she said, congratulations, and what do you think of that variegated monstera, and we answered with the confidence of people who had recently survived a meteorological reminder that none of this is guaranteed. At QuikTrip, the cashier with the eyeliner said, honey, of course, and gave us two extra packs of ketchup unasked, and June whispered to me that this is how institutions redeem themselves, and I nodded like a parishioner.

The radio offered me a slot on a public show about local culture because someone had decided I was local and culture, and I said yes because my mother learned who I was from church bulletins first and NPR second. The host had a voice like someone you want to invite to narrate your home movies, and he asked about the ice storm and bowls and a cross that can’t make up its mind, and halfway through he asked, very gently, what it is like to love someone in a place that doesn’t always know how to file the paperwork for what you feel. I smiled at the engineer window that keeps you humble and said that love is a form and a performance and a kitchen and a community and a QuikTrip, and that we don’t need the room to clap as long as the room lets us find each other without pretending not to be cold. He said thank you in the way people say thank you when the word is doing push-ups, and after we were off-air he showed me his wallet where he keeps a folded photo of a man and a toddler in a pool, and I told him the water makes their shoulders happy, and he said, I know, and we stood there for a second inside a quiet that didn’t want to end.

We got invited to dinner by June’s father because men who fix things eventually figure out that stew is another form of repair. He lived in a house on the outside edge of town where the lawns are tired by October and the fences have evidence of teenagers leaning. He had hands that underlined and a laugh stored in that chest voice men think they invented, and he greeted June with an inspection that doubled as love. I stood in the door with my polite coat and the gift of coffee my mother insisted you bring a person who thinks filters are fancy, and he nodded at me like I had told him something printable. He asked what I do and I said I tell the truth out loud until someone cares, and he said, sounds expensive, and I said it pays in soup, which pleased him because all fathers I have ever met appreciate a barter. During dinner he asked exactly two questions that were direct and one that went in sideways and all of them said, I would like to learn how to trust what you tell my daughter you will do. June answered him with the patience of a student who has been preparing for this oral exam since childhood, and afterward we sat on the couch and watched a football game no one really believed in, and he asked me what I thought about the cross on the highway, and I told him the joke, and he laughed in that particular male way that means you have been inducted into a club that does not have a charter, and when we left he handed June a small toolbox she had left there at twenty-two, and I realized that forgiveness sometimes looks like returning a borrowed thing that never should have been kept.

The first really cold show of the season was a bonfire in a backyard with a stage made from the promise of plywood. The host had strung Edison bulbs across oaks that had recovered from the ice like veterans, and the audience sat on lawn chairs and warm beverages and a day’s worth of decisions. I wore boots with soles thick enough to negotiate and a sweater my sister calls an apology, and the mic behaved like a good dog who knows where to sit. I told new jokes about soup as liturgy and paperwork as a love language, and I tried the one about saying girlfriend in rooms that can’t decide if they’re gyms or rec centers, and the laughter climbed over the fence and went to the next yard without asking permission because the night needed to be shared. June stood near the fire with her hands out in that old prayer and her junior-high student Ava huddled beside her throwing her chips back into the bag like she was feeding a fish. After the show a man with a tattoo of a storm cell on his forearm told me he named it after his daughter because he wanted her to remember to be big, and I nodded like the night wasn’t now wanting to make me simpler.

At some point the two of us took a Sunday nap like a sacrament. The sky wore flannel and the BA Expressway hummed with its November hymn and we lay on the couch we had acquired together and fell asleep in a way I will never be able to perform onstage with integrity. When we woke, the light in the living room had moved to the spot that makes dust look like a decision, and June’s hair left a pattern on my forearm that I wished I could keep in clay. We ate leftover stew from her father’s house and bread we pretended to have baked on purpose, and the heavy bowl sat between us like a third presence that had begun to offer opinions. I told June that one day I want to do a show in a room that serves soup from a pot instead of from a bar, and she said one day she wants to teach a class where no one apologizes for gravity, and we wrote these things on paper that already had grocery lists on it, and the lists looked like a map of a life we had always meant to arrive at.

It was the kind of winter day where the sky wore its best stern face when the library hosted a panel on banned books that included me by accident because someone saw my bit online and decided metaphor qualified as expertise. The room was warm with coats that had given up and pockets that had held cords and cookies and petitions, and the table at the front had four people who had all been told no at some point and had looked at the word like it was plastic. A teacher talked about reading a novel to a class whispering because her principal didn’t understand that whispering is holy and the librarian described the box where people can leave angry notes and the notes that weren’t angry but used the same font, and I said that laughter is a way we prove to ourselves we can still move air through our bodies when what is happening asks us not to. Someone in the back asked if comedy is dangerous, and I said yes and it is also the blanket the dog will not surrender because it smells like everyone, and the audience made that sound again, the one that says we have decided, for the next hour, to tell the truth with supervision. After, we put out the heavy bowl with pens and asked for titles of books that taught people how to live inside a house with weather, and the words came in small careful handwriting like we were willing spells into being, and I wanted to drive to the city councilmembers’ houses and pour the bowl onto their doorsteps like a blessing they did not ask for and cannot return.

The heater in my apartment developed an opinion about working when asked, and I called the landlord and he sent a man named RON who wore shorts because the universe enjoys the callback more than any of us do. He stood in my living room with those knobby knees that have seen too many summers and said he would persuade the unit to recall its purpose, and I made small talk about ice storms and resilience and bowl-based relationships because silence in my home while a man touches the walls makes me feel like the house will develop bad habits. He asked if the heavy bowl was an heirloom, and I told him yes, from a future we’ve already met, and he laughed in that way contractors laugh when they are fond of your pipes. He left with the heater grudgingly employed and a warning about filters, and June and I changed the thermostat to a modest number that would have made my grandmother proud, and we sat on the floor in our socks eating oranges because we are determined to be a cliche that earns its keep, and the peels made the room smell like a sunny day we did not deserve, and we decided to keep deserving it for as long as we could manipulate the angles.

On a Wednesday that pretended to be Monday I forgot my set list and learned a new kind of faith. I stood in front of a room with a face and a mic with a history and I opened my mouth and asked the day to tell me what it wanted to hear, and it offered me the story of the warming center and the paperwork and the way we use both hands and the teenagers who bring their broken cylinders to a teacher with a laugh that proves there is no wrong shape. I talked about the way June touches clay like it was always a person and about the church potluck where Sister Evelyn policed mayonnaise and about how we are all keeping pilot lights alive with hair dryers and stubbornness, and the audience gave me the kind of attention that feels like a loan and a gift at once. After, I wrote the set down from memory and found the gaps where fear had been, and I folded the paper and slid it into the bowl on my table like I was storing it for a day when flames might ask to be useful again.

When December came with its list of obligations and oranges and the traffic’s costume, we bought lights. We strung them around the balcony railing like we were claiming jurisdiction over a tiny square of sky and we put a small string inside the heavy bowl like we were daring it to be ridiculous, and the glow made the fruit look like it had opinions. My mother brought us a wreath she pretended not to have made, and we hung it with a zip tie because neither of us wanted to trust ribbon, and June tied a red string around the weather radio’s antenna because all gods appreciate decor. We wrote cards with messages we had earned this year because writing words to people you love knowing the weather might not let you say them later is a practice I recommend, and we put stamps on them like a choir uniform. On the night the church hosted Lessons and Carols and the sanctuary smelled like fake pine and real breath, we sat in the back and let the carols do their work, and my mother’s alto was the meeting point of all the roads we had taken to get here, and when the congregation stood for “O Little Town of Bethlehem,” I squeezed June’s hand and felt the bowl again, offered by the night to the two of us with both hands.Chapter 10

The morning after Lessons and Carols puts starch in the sky and steam on our windows, and the radio says words like wind chill with the sternness of a parent who has earned it. My mother’s alto still hums in the hinge of my jaw and June’s hair smells like the lobby of a church that got away with something honest. We make coffee with the reverence of people who have come to enjoy surviving, and we put the heavy bowl on the table because it has opinions about method. December asks its perennial questions—whose house, which meal, what names—and we answer them with compromise and a calendar and the word girlfriend lodged in our throats like a peppermint that refuses to dissolve. June’s sister texts about socks versus slippers in a tone that implies jurisprudence, and my father sends a photo of a snow shovel he has repainted for the third time because tools are family in his hands, and the BA Expressway sings its winter hymn in the distance like a machine we now trust on purpose.

We plan a thing with the audacity that only new steadiness can permit. We call it Both Hands Night because we are sentimental enough to name a feeling and practical enough to invite people to stand in it. It will be a living room show and a soup line, a fundraiser for the library’s banned books fund disguised as a reason to bring folding chairs into our apartment and test the architecture of what we have built. I make a list that reads like a cross between a grocery run and liturgy—ladle, napkins, mic stand borrowed from the youth group, index cards, extension cord that does not want to be an optimist, Sister Evelyn’s approval, three kinds of bread, a jar for the librarian who brings receipts as proof of virtue, and the heavy bowl at the center like a planet. June makes her own list that involves clay and cups and signage and the particular way she arranges light so that hands look like they always knew how to do this.

The invitations go out with the daring of people who pretend not to care how many chairs they will have to find in neighboring apartments. We text the muralist who eats granola bars like they are cigarettes and the librarian whose cardigan has been promoted to armor, the teenager Ava who learned to center by making peace with breath, Mr. Lopez because theology deserves to be brought a spoon, the man with the reflective vest who always tips at QuikTrip as if we are all a band playing his favorite song. I ask the comics who owe me fifteen minutes and a fraction of their good behavior, my mother because every room benefits from at least one person who knows when to pass you a tissue without making it a conversation, and my father because the shelf he will inevitably hang in his mind will keep the ceiling up better than the beams. June invites her students and her sister and, bravely, her father, because repair looks like stew until it looks like chairs lined up in a room that smells like onions and hope.

On the day, the sky gives us a light that believes in faces, and the apartment turns obediently into a venue because venues are simply rooms with concentrated consent. We shove the couch into the hallway, a move my neighbors accept because they also mistrust furniture that thinks it matters, and we line up chairs borrowed from the church, the plant shop, and a neighbor who insists the chairs not be used for politics but concedes that soup is bipartisan. June places cups on a folding table with a precision that convinces me of free will and arranges a small ceramic placard that reads HANDLE WITH BOTH HANDS in the script that would talk you out of a fight. I string the lights I bought in a fit of optimism around the doorway in a loop that would not satisfy my mother but pleases the room, and I tape a cable to the carpet because I want to be the kind of host who thinks about tripping hazards and metaphors. The heavy bowl sits on the dining table like a throne seat for something we don’t have a name for yet, and when Sister Evelyn arrives with a pot that has to be carried by two people whose biceps are making a case for sainthood, the bowl allows itself to be filled with a confidence that makes me stand up straighter.

People come in carrying their versions of themselves assigned to December. There are coats with ambitions and scarves that tell family stories, cheeks with weather built into them, hands ready to be offered to coats and bowls and each other. The librarian places a cardboard sign next to the bowl that says YOUR TITLES HERE, and she smuggles a plastic box of pens onto the table as if some bureaucrat might fling open the door and demand to see our literature permits. Mr. Lopez carries a tin of cookies that tastes like his grandmother used a recipe she once copied incorrectly and refused to fix because delicious mistakes deserve loyalty. The muralist leans a print of our town against the radiator, a map that refuses to obey directions, and the reflective vest men arrive in civilian sweaters and look confused by their softness until they accept that coats do not decide the policies of hearts. My mother kisses June’s cheek and slips into the kitchen to wash the two dishes I have left in the sink on purpose because she measures my love in objects she can make shine, and my father checks the stability of the mic stand with the same intensity he applies to cabinets because a toppled mic is an insult to his trade.

The show begins because the soup is poured and because June touches my arm in that way that makes me understand why people bow before they open their mouths. I welcome the room like I am greeting a congregation that has woken up to find their sanctuary relocated into an apartment where the thermostat has been negotiated into kindness. I tell them I am not a pastor but I am a practitioner of timing, which is our city’s second religion after weather, and I ask them to set their phones to the mode that implies we could be interrupted by only a kiss or a fire, and tonight the former is preferred. The librarian says three sentences about books and one about courage that lands softly and then refuses to leave, and the muralist reads street names off her own body and we recognize them because they have been ours long enough to become muscle memory. A comic I adore does five minutes about his grandmother’s pilot light that makes me reconsider the word eternal in theologies I inherited, and Mr. Lopez mutters something to the ceiling that I cannot translate but trust anyway.

June stands up and the room tilts toward her the way wheat tilts toward wind that will not start a fight. She talks about centering and about the difference between control and conversation, and the teenagers in the room sit up like people whose bodies have just been given an alternate set of instructions. She holds up a cup and shows us the lip that forgives your mouth for being a mouth, and then she places both hands on the heavy bowl like an altar that prefers honesty to incense and says, we made this, which is a sentence I have waited all my life to attach to something that outweighs me. She tells a story about a student who thought breaking meant failure and how the kiln sometimes argues with you in a tone that requires you to answer with a jacket and a walk, and when she finishes the librarian folds her hands in the way that gets people to pay their fines and says, amen, because not all rituals need to be copyrighted.

I do my set with an ear for the room we have built together, skipping the line about the elastic in her hair because it still belongs too much to the skin of the two of us and not enough to the plank we agreed to share. I talk about ice and the warming center and my mother’s soap operas with scripture soundtracks and the giant cross at the highway that cannot make up its mind between billboard and benediction. I do the new line about checking the partner box and how the word sounds like we are qualified to repair fencing and also declare bankruptcy in a manner that preserves dignity, and the laugh that comes back is the good one, the one that arrives with both hands. The reflective vest men raise their paper cups in a toast that is also consent, and the teenager Ava snorts in the back because she just learned what snorting can accomplish. When I say girlfriend, I can feel the room check its pockets for the appropriate reaction and then find it: they do not applaud like a wedding, they do not cough like a jury, they simply breathe in a way that allows the word to sit on the table without flinching, and that is enough for now.

We pass the bowl for titles and money because money matters and because titles are money other people forgot to print, and the librarian whispers when she counts because whispering has always been her preferred form of celebration. People write the names of books they were told not to read and the names of people who told them to read anyway, and the cards slide against each other with a sound I would save in a jar if I could. A woman whose face looks like it has faced a winter says she has an extra space heater if anyone’s house is arguing with pipes, and a man who learned to fix roofs on his father’s knees offers his Saturday to a stranger because generosity is a skill you practice in public. My mother stands near the door with a basket of cloth napkins like the gatekeeper to a better table and blesses each forehead with her eyes because she never learned the fine art of letting people leave without a benediction, and my father sneaks out to tighten the screws on our coat rack because he has a thing about load-bearing declarations.

There is a flicker in the lights because December thinks it’s funny and the room does what rooms do when electricity makes choices—we hold very still and decide who we are in flicker. The string of bulbs pretends to be a miracle and the candles that June put into jars of beans behave like they were waiting to be invited to leadership, and someone in the back remembers a flashlight and someone else remembers that sometimes the best room is the one where you can see only as far as the next face. We do the last five minutes without amplification which feels like walking a dog without a leash and discovering it knows your name better than you do, and when I thank everyone and the librarian says she has never seen so many people look at a bowl like it was a suggestion from the future, something inside me clicks with the gentle authority of a lock that knows it is guarding something we will want back.

After, the cleanup behaves like a family reunion we approve of. The musicians without instruments stack chairs, the teenagers wash dishes with theatrical sighs, my father finds the one wobbly leg on the folding table and tutors it toward fidelity, Sister Evelyn wraps the last of the bread in foil and tells me not to refrigerate it as if she could crawl through my fridge after midnight to correct me if I try, and the muralist stands on the balcony smoking a granola bar and telling the Christmas lights across the courtyard that they are doing good work. June and I move around each other like we have earned choreography, and when we meet at the sink with the bowl between us it feels like we are proposing to the same entity at the same time. We wash it with that attention you reserve for ceremonial objects and newborns and heirlooms from futures, and the drips run down our forearms like a blessing that got its act together.
